												After finishing Skyrim I did not want to play through it again and waste another a hundred hours of my time in this complex sandbox game. However, I was still addicted to its sandbox formula and the kind of freedom it offered. So I began my quest to seek something that could cure my itch. I came across the Gothic and Risen series and read up on its development history so I purchased both to see if they would satisfy my itch. Being a huge Skyrim fan, I will be making many comparisons between the two games within this review. You have been warned.Plot: 3/5Personally, I enjoy playing games that have a deep, well woven plot. I understand open ended gameplay is a big thing right now (e.g. Dayz, Minecraft), but for me I find that after playing these games for a period of time, they begin to feel mechanical and repetitive. The plot in Risen can't be considered superb, but it does its job to keep me engegd the whole time. The player character possesses a very bland personality and his voice acting is also very stiff. In my opinion, I would rather prefer to not have the player character be given an identity or voice at all. A good RPG should be immersive. So much so that the player should feel like they are exploring a whole new world and their actions are going to have an impact on this world. Without this immersion, the game becomes a grind just like those free to play mmorpgs. Elements like drugs and prostitution are also sort of lame. They aren't outrageously over the top like the way The Witcher does it and they aren't exactly sensual and emotional like Mass Effect or Dragon Age. However, I really liked the way factions were implemented in this game. It was very hard for me to decide which factions to join at the start of the game because I couldn't tell who were the good guys or bad guys.Gameplay mechanics: 2.5/5This is the part of the game that really didn't sit well with me. First of all, I hated Risen's map system. I understand that for authenticity sake the player must first seek out an expert to draw a map before it becomes available for use, but even then, the map was confusing to use and I probably spent half of my time in this game running around and unable to find my way. The quest prompts were also too vague and I find the inclusion of the conversations with the quest giver to be utterly pointless. The varieties of creatures to fight in this game were also abysmal. Once the Lizardmen made their appearance encounters with other enemies became greatly reduced. To be fair the gameplay mechanics isn't all bad. I really liked some of the skills in this game. For example, I had a blast floating around with the levitation spell, and the in game traps were also well designed too.Music: 2.5/5I may not be an music expert, but Skyrim's Dragonborn theme song and the female vocals that play during Dragonage's menu screen still resonates in my head from time to time. Risen lacks the sort of musical score which can make a memorable impact on its players but they are still nice to listen to. I do like some of the music that plays during battles or in the background as I explored the wilderness. For example, as I was exploring a dark ruin, the creepy ambient sound and loud shrieks really put a chill down my spine.Graphics: 4/5Depending on your systems, this game can be very pretty. The lighting and reflections were gorgeous and I took a lot of screenshots of the beautiful scenery. Final Score: 3/5 A good game, but only if you got it as part of a deal.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Skyrim通关以后不愿意再打开算是一种精神洁癖，认为游戏玩通关了就应该放下了， 繁复去玩让人头疼。但是对于sandbox游戏的热爱让我又开始寻找上古的替代品， 于是知道了gothic和risen系列， 只购买了piranha – bytes工作室制作的那几部。既然玩了，难免要和上古做个比较。 故事情节：3/5 之所以把故事放在最前面讲，是因为我是比较看重这个部分的。有一些游戏貌似很自由很开放，你在这个世界什么都可以做，例如最近热门的那些僵尸类游戏，但是玩久了你就会觉得有种机械工的感觉， 不停重复去做一件事情，乏味的很。而risen在故事设计上只能算是刚刚好，首先主角的性格就不那么明晰，配音也很僵硬，不如没有配音。 其余的配角的性格反超主角，这也是为什么大家都很喜欢patty而嫌弃男主，就是这样的原因。 一个好的rpg，要让玩家真正完全带入到角色中去，让自己感觉这个屏幕里奔跑的小人就是我自己，而不是一个杀怪的苦力。游戏中的抽大麻和妓女的设定觉得很无聊， 根本就是打擦边球，还不如直接干到巫师的级别，很黄很暴力， 要么就学学质量效应和龙纪元，玩玩暧昧。但是值得肯定， 游戏里游戏的阵营设定确实不错，这也是加分的一点，一开始确实让人不知所措，我该相信谁的话总是萦绕在脑中。最后犯贱的看了攻略才算石头落地。游戏设定：2.5/5为什么给了这么低的分数， 也许这样的系统设定真的不太适合我。。。首先习惯了上古那种地图以后这个游戏完全是生命在吐槽的感觉。。。我倒不反对地图为了逼真要真的去请人画地图，或者从一些探险者身上去扒取，我无法忍受的是地图给了就和没给一样，有些时候时间根本没有浪费在剧情上， 完全是浪费在迷路上了， 任务写的不明不白也就算了，你把一些有的没的对话写在上面是闹哪样啊！ 强烈不建议没玩过此类rpg的同学玩这个游戏，会十分不适应。。。要时刻记住，做好一个rpg游戏应尽的本分，不要弄弄就变成生存游戏了哦，玩家会闹情绪的说。而且怪物的种类真的少到要大姨妈都不想来了， 后面蜥蜴人一出来其他怪物数量大减啊，蜥蜴人是在刷存在么， 根本就是偷懒好么！ 但是一些技能真的很好玩，那个悬浮技能啊，飘来飘去的， 还有各种机关陷阱。。。音乐： 2.5/5好的音乐是什么。。。就是skyrim一打开那两句：dovakin dovakin，或者龙纪元一开始那个哼哼唧唧老娘们的吟唱， 一辈子都忘不掉。。。你问我risen是什么开头音乐。。。昨晚刚玩呢都不记得了我打开再听听。。。。 一些环境和战斗的音乐还是比较好的，特别是进第一个ruin的时候那个鬼叫给我吓毁了。。。画面：4/5在那个年代应该算不错的了吧。。。还是截了一些比较美丽的图片。。。总体3/5， 百分制就60分。。。艾玛。。。尊低。。。

content:
Posted: September 15, 2016
												Risen is a game that just simply grows on you. It starts out as a simple something and infects you like some kind of benign, beautiful infection.It's the story.It's combat is simple, yet effective. It's skillset is just the right balance of simplicity and growth. It's not linear, and yet, it uses the difficulty of the environment to keep you from moving beyond where the story wants you to go. It's open world and yet your skillset and loadout will keep you where the story wants you.The mobs you encounter don't level up with you, giving you the satisfaction of whipping the siht out of a mob today that you had trouble with a while back. Each time you get smacked you can confidently nurse your wounds and walk away muttering, "I'll be back you bsatrad!" And you will be back... and you'll be back ready to utterly destroy them. Sweet satisfaction. You can ONLY get this kind of revenge in a video game. That said, save often! Get very familiar with the "Quick Save" button.And the story moves on. It took me well into the 3rd chapter before I had to search online to understand how to do something.The acting is great for a video game... and unexexpected for it's age.I have, at the time of this writing, just 54 hours in the game... and just as I was thinking it's about to wrap up the story, it continues. Fantastic! The quality has caused me to search out a whole series of games I didn't know existed.As for "cons" I would mention the graphics... but that wouldn't be fair as I'm sure they were revolutionary for the time it was created. And they're actually beautiful with the way it does its blurring affect on things that aren't supposed to be in focus and other scenery. It's simply outstanding. It's the edges and corners that give its age away. Other than the occasional glitches that occur when you get jammed up against a wall and can see the scenery behind it suddenly, I haven't found any bugs.In short, it's well thought out, a story that is well written, a program thoroughly baked and bug free, combat and experience growth well balanced and satisfaction in just the right places.If you're into dungeons and RPG and over the shoulder combat, you'll enjoy it.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
												In my opinion most should ONLY play this game if they've already finished multiple playthroughs of TES 3, 4 & 5. If the fantasy setting and roleplaying are what you're looking for, add Witcher 1&2 and Dragon Age Origins to that list, and if open-world gameplay is what you're after, add Fallout 3 and NV.This game is one of the most solidly "slightly below average" games I've ever played. No aspect of this game is better than the equivalent mechanic/quality in Elder Scrolls Oblivion, and many aspects are worse than even Morrowind, a considerably older game. On top of that, there is plenty of plain old BAD DESIGN in the story, quests and levelling that shouldn't be excusable, but are unfortunatly trademarks of Piranha Bytes.STORY is sparse, forgettable and poorly told. While the setting is an interesting one, the story just isn't really there, the end villain seems added on at the last minute, and none of the characters are memorable, except maybe the player chacter.GRAPHICS are ok, around Oblivion quality but with much better lighting for the most part. A big issue, though is that there is no Gamma slider. The Devs, apparently wanted nighttime/caves to be REALLY REALLY DARK as some form of "realism", but this makes sections of the game unplayable if your computer isn't located in a very very dark room, unless you make use of torches/light spells, which in turn make gameplay even more clunky. BAD DESIGN CHOICE!SOUND - some better-than-average voice acting mixed with some really amateurish voice acting. Totally forgettable sound effects and music, compounded by a bug (fixable by fanpatches) that breaks music in-game due to some sloppy sound file editing by the devs. GAMEPLAY:COMBAT is quit punishing/unforgiving early on due to the BAD DESIGN CHOICE of making armor only upgradeable at the end of each chapter. Enemies don't respawn, and the game is "Open World", but if you try to explore in the first couple chapters when decent armor isn't available, you'll be killed in 1-4 hits from most enemies. The combat system seems "deep" when you first start playing, but in reality each enemy type follows a set pattern and once you figure that out and have some ok armor, they are universally easy and actually don't really possess any sort of AI.OPEN WORLD really is open and you can basically go everywhere on the island from the get go. I like the fact that enemies don't respawn, which helps in the exploration process. I pretty much explored the entire island in "Chapter 2" out of 4, which made Chapters 3&4 only a couple of hours long each. The world is relatively SMALL, and there are only 3 real "types" of environment besides dungeon/caves, so there isn't so much variety.CHOICE is poorly handled. The story is almost completely linear, and dialogue options aren't really options, as no branching conversations are possible, and you end up getting 100% of dialogue no matter what order you ask your questions. All conversations could in reality have been non-interactive cutscenes. WITHOUT A WALKTHROUGH IT'S ALMOST PURE CHANCE WHICH CLASS YOU'LL END UP AS, which is frustrating, and the only real choice in the game only affects a small part of the early plot. THIS CHOICE IS EASILY BROKEN if you do a few quests for both factions. In my playthrough, I did some of each factions' quests, and ended up members of "both" which broke certain aspects of the game and made parts of the game not make sense. Only after this started getting weird, when reading a walkthrough for the first time to try and figure out what went wrong did I find out that PIRANHA BYTES simply DID A HORRIBLE JOB PLANNING AND EXECUTING THE STORY STRUCTURE AND DESIGN. Judging from most internet forums on the matter, most people who didn't use a walkthrough got ♥♥♥♥ed in some way while playing the game.OTHER BAD DESIGN DECISIONS BY PIRANHA BYTES about in Risen. Stats can be boosted up to 100 by trainers, but well over 100 by potions. The game doesn't tell you this, though, so if you find and use the potions before training up to 100, you basically waste them. And if you have stat-affecting items on while training, you actually break the training process and LOWER how high you can train your stats. HORRIBLE DESIGN THAT WAS LEFT UNPATCHED BY A BAD DEVELOPER.THE ENDGAME IS A LAZY BOSS FIGHT THAT HAS NOTHING TO DO WITH THE REST OF THE GAME IN TERMS OF GAMEPLAY. It is followed by the games only pre-rendered cutscene followed by a black screen with a short voiceover, the credits and BANG - back to the main menu with no option to further explore the world.Anyways, I should mention that I inadvertantly left the game running for a little over a day in the background, so while my record says over 50 hours played, I actually finished the game in about 25 hours and did pretty much everything possible in a single playthrough.I enjoyed the first 10 hours or so in which I was exploring the island and not really advancing the main story, but after that, the horrible, sloppy design and gameplay elements began to manifest, and the last 10-15 hours were quite a grind. I honestly wish I'd just given up and had a 3rd playthrough of an Elder Scrolls game or the Witcher instead.Piranha Bytes should be ashamed that most of their games are broken/buggy and that they rely on fan patches and walkthroughs for players to be able to finish their games. I know they don't have Bethesda's kind of budget, but that isn't an excuse for releasing broken, mediocre games.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												After the somewhat abrupt and premature ending in Gothic 3 and the separation of Piranha Bytes from the publisher and the Gothic Franchise, fans welcomed the new game by Piranha Bytes, Risen. I was more than interested to see if the game was going to be a continuation of the Gothic series and whether it could capture the atmosphere of the world of Gothic. I would classify this under two headings. With respect to the continuation of the story, there was not much and there wasn't much they could do about it probably, what with the copyright issues and all. They did however use the same theme of what was left of the world after the events in Gothic 3 (won't mention them here to avoid spoilers).As for gameplay, I was not disappointed though I did feel that there were several areas they could have improved. Firstly, the world is not open; it is quite small and limited, even compared to RPGs at around the same time. Secondly, the gameplay is similar to that of Gothic 3, which brings the advantage of commonality for Gothic players but has a Learning Curve for new players (people who bought Risen and never played the Gothic titles). Thirdly, the magic combat/use is lacking; you can only have one active spell effect at a time. For example, (you cannot have boost armor and boost strength at the same time). So far as the story goes, I can say that Piranha did a good job and the Gothic fans should not be disappointed; at least I wasn't but of course that's just my opinion.I just felt the ending was a little too quick...

Posted: October 13, 2016
												It definitely has the Gothic DNA and a lot of the elements that made Gothic great are still here: a merc camp, a bustling town, and little pockets of ruins peppered throughout the wilderness. Exploring is still the main highlight of the game, here, however, the combat lacks the charm of the original series and follows a boring rhythm based combat system. Enemies will almost always block some of your attacks, which adds to the tedium since if you're beefing up a combat skill in particular it doesn't feel like your're a master swordsman at all. The game follows tradition and has a pretty grindy final act where you face TONS of enemies in armor, thankfully here it's easy to run past most enemies. All in all a solid title that doesn't retain all of what made Gothic great but has enough to warrant a playthrough, though I won't blame you for jumping ship before the final boss.Positive note: I do like how they add traversal tools, e.g. telekinesis, transformation, it enhances the exploration and is something I want to see in Elex! Hopefully they nail the feel of the skill AND item progression.Something that bothered me was that no matter how badass your armor is, every enemy will make you stagger if they connect w a hit, even a ♥♥♥♥ing pig, dog or squirrel. I remember getting good armor in Gothic and smiling as I saw the wolves and scavengers graze me.

Posted: February 19, 2014
												It would be hard to hard to argue with someone saying this game is kind of ♥♥♥♥♥♥. It can be buggy, dated, and hackneyed at times. But if you're like me, and loved every second of the Gothic games, this game is a great update on the model. In fact, it's basically a remake of Gothic. This game/series has an open world exploration model unlike any other. For one thing, there is a finite amount of XP in the game. So grinding is impossible. That's ♥♥♥♥ing cool. Plus, you can wander virtually anywhere. The game doesn't really mind too much (i.e. it doesn't break) if you glitch your way into certain areas too early or whatever. What mostly keeps you out of places that you're not supposed to get to is that you'll get your♥♥♥♥♥beat. Monsters don't scale with level, and pretty much all of them are tougher than you at the outset. The actual role-playing isn't that deep (this game is the anti-bioware), but that doesn't mean that it's not fun to explore and immerse yourself in a new world. If you can put up with some flaws and imperfections, then this is a fun and unique (outside of Gothic) romp.

												The real "Gothic 4." I prefer the story, setting, and factions in the Gothic games (Gothic's fantasy prison setting is way more interesting than Risen's rather generic tropical island), but "Risen" improves on the series in terms of gameplay. Combat is much easier to manage and while the open world does have some incredibly difficult enemies blocking off certain areas, they seem much less like arbitrary barriers as it's possible for the patient player to outwit and even destroy them early on (when I played, for example, I went exploring early on and accidentally found the best weapon in the game by running from/sniping the high level cave monsters guarding it. It isn't often that RPGs will let you just stumble onto and use high level main quest items before you even figure out what the main quest is). Like "Gothic" things degenerate into a linear monster grind in the very last hours of the game, but that's a minor quibble (someday PB will nail an ending...someday). Still, a great ARPG.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												With over 30+ hours into this game I can say this is one of the best role playing games I've ever played.Risen is a great hybrid of modern gaming sensability mixed with a heavy dose of classic old school game play. It's certainly not a game for everyone, and those looking for refined combat mechanics or hack and slash gameplay will be disappointed. At it's core, Risen is about exploration, communication, steady character improvement, and mystery solving. The story starts off pretty simple with a shipwrecked character that lacks any significant backstory. While modern gamers may see this as a negative, it's actually one of the game's greatest strengths. The whole idea of the classic RPG was to let your character forge a story as they interacted and played through the campaign. Risen grants players the freedom to choose a faction, choose their skills and talents, and ultimately decide to be a nice guy or a total ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. You'll talk to people to solve quests that grant experience and rewards, play people against one another, and unlock the secrets of the island and the catastrophe plaguing the world.The other great stregnth of this game is exploration. The Island is a beautifully handcrafted and seamless world. It's large enough to allow you to take your time and explore every nook and cranny for enemy encounters, crafting materials and treasure, but not so big and generic that it ever feels tedious running around on your quests. Later in the game, it becomes much easier to move about and track down things you might have missed.So to wrap things up, here's a list of positives and negatives:Positives:- well crafted seamless world full of secrets and hours upon hours of exploration- camps and towns feel alive with NPCs who have various quests and belong to various factions with their own motivations- lots of skills to learn and items to find and craft- choose your path, and become a mage, fighter, rogue or a combination of any of those skillsetsNegatives:- combat feels a little stiff and clunky - can be frustrating to figure everything out at the start for newcomers to RPGsMy rating:☺☺☺☺☺Five happy faces!

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												I'm a huge fan of RPGs, it's my favorite genre by far, and generally I'm hard to please. There's this certain kind of undefinable sublime quality of the Risen franchise, and with the first game in particular. It's in a fantasy setting, but with a gritty, hard-edged feeling that I immediately took a liking to. The game franchise shares a pedigree with the Gothic games (both developed by Piranha Bytes, but the Risen games having a seperate publisher) and I've read several times that in truth, the Risen franchise is really the spiritual successor of the Gothic games.You can spot the similarities between the two series easily. In both series you play a "nameless hero". You have no character customization in Risen, you start as a stowaway on an Inquisition ship that capsizes and sinks. You find yourself washed up on the shore of Faranga, a large volcanic, mediterranean-like island. The game is open world, limited of course by the fact that the game does, of course, take place on an island. No worries here, the island is quite large, with various climates and distinctive areas.As someone who loves to role-play, I really enjoyed playing a character that has virtually no back-story, not even a name. The game presents you oppourtunities to shape what kind of character you're going to be. Similar to the Witcher games, choices are often morally ambiguous. Neutrality is sometimes what the situations is called for, and often towing the line between being a hero or a heartless thug was really enjoyable.That, of course, can't last forever. Eventually you'll have to align yourself with one of the two factions struggling for control of Faranga. The quests are numerous, and surprisingly contain few "fetch" quests. The writing is excellent, in my opinion, and the voice-over work really quite well done. The developers don't exactly hold your hand when it comes to the often multilayerd and multistaged quests. A certain amount of cleverness is required of the player, and I've found wrapping up quests very rewarding.I chose to go the route of the Fighter, and I've found the combat very enjoyable. It requires mastering the use of block and parry, counter-parry and attack. Leveling your character is also an interesting experience. At each level you're given 10 learning points. Depending on what you're going for, you'll need to seek out the assistance of trainers who can help you increase your statistics and skills. Right away I invested in swordsmanship, and strength, but also in sneaking and lockpicking. I found that gathering a lot of "thief" skills was a fantastic (and fun) way to finance my adventures. You can also dedicate yourself to the Ranger-type character, or a magic-user. Or mix it up, which I definitely recommend.The game's visuals can sometimes leave a little bit to be desired, but truthfully I found I really enjoyed the style and the art in the game. It grew on me quickly, and I found myself snapping screenshots of areas and events I particularly liked.To be clear, I've not yet finished all of the game. I'm nearing Chapter 3, which I believe is the final chapter. During nearly all my playtime, I had to play in Steam's Offline mode so my tracked game time on Steam is lower than the actual number.To wrap up, I highly recommend this game to fans of the hand-crafted RPG. That kind of RPG that you can tell a team put their blood, sweat and tears into. It has huge depth, it's very rewarding. 4 out of 5 stars. Go get it.

												I picked this up in a bundle somewhere a while back and didn't really think much about it, I picked the bundle up for something else and this just happened to be in it. I spotted it in my library earlier today and headed off to the store page to see what it was and read a review that was basically saying "Go play the game now!"So I did, and I'm so glad I did too! I've barely scratched the surface of this game and already have quests coming out my ears, I've died more times than I care to admit and still can't remember what buttons I need to be pressing a lot of the time, but I love it!It does seem to have some bugs, there have been times I can't draw my weapon in the usual way (thankfully there is another way around that, which I worked out in the end) and at one point I couldn't get my character to run, again I worked round it. These are only small annoyances though, and really only tiny once you realise there is a way around these problems.The graphics are great, considering this is a 2009 game, just make sure you have the graphics settings to high. The graphics and audio combined make quite the immersive world that really sucks you in, which is just what you want for an RPG.The game is far from easy, heck I died countless times before I'd really moved from my starting point! Things will kill you and they can and will kill you fast. Saving regularly is a must here unless you like replaying all that progress you just made. So far I'm really enjoying this and really glad that I just happened to pick it up, along with Risen 2, it is truly a hidden gem in my library that I'm glad I dusted off.

It's from 2009, yes, but it is still really good and better than a lots of other modern RPGs. The enemys are not leveling up, which I really like cause its totally unrealistic when a wolf grows stronger and stronger and had at the end 10 times more damage. 												I want to give a short review of this game. I found the difficulty frustrating at certain points but nothing that some patience couldn't solve. This is NOT the game where you can just run into room and expect to live without careful planning. The plot was decent but nothing surprising. The game does make you feel like rising up the ranks as you can grow from a cast-away on a beach into the most important person in the game. One aspect of the story that I really enjoyed was that early on I was captured by the "enemy" due to my own incompetence and instead of ending the game there I was taken to the monastery and trained to be a warrior of the inquisition. My very path being changed completely due to a mistake I did early on was an extremely refreshing change from normal RPGs and I applaud the devs for that decision.Overall I did enjoy the game even though some design decisions and bugs had me frustrated. I give it a solid 7/10 and a must-play for hardcore RPG fans and I recommendation for purchase in a sale for the others.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												Risen is a throwback to the days when Gothic 1 and Gothic 2 were considered kings of RPGs. After Piranha Bytes failed with Gothic 3, and the franchise went to other developers, they cut back on ambition and delivered an experience much like Gothic 1. This experience consists of being a funny bigmouth, that starts as a complete newcomer and nobody in a fairly isolated, but lively territory, full of political intrigues, other bigmouths and hordes of monsters that will help you advance in your career as the local tough guy. The game is very combat-centric, and quite tough, but also very rewarding - every new piece of gear or move is a big thing in Risen, and might spell doom for the monster that you weren't able to take on previously, and, thus, allow you to explore some more of the fairly beautiful world. Other attractions include dealing with pirates, smoking (swamp)weed and searching unsuccessfully for a guy you're supposed to meet in a brothel. And lots more!the biggest downside this game has (and the previous gothic games, too, really) is the radical difference between early-to-mid game and late-game. just be prepared that this game becomes more and more combat-centric the deeper you get.totally recommended, though.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												Risen is.... a good game. But very hard. At least, to me it is. It actually took me more than an hour to start enjoying Risen but once I got into it I couldn't stop playing. The Dialogue is hilarious at times and the main character often insults others in very amusing ways. The game is realistic in it's day and night and weather cycles and also how NPCs treat you based on how you treat them. There are many different abilities to teach your character and the game allows you to chose your own play-stlye. There are also usually multiple ways to complete quests which is a plus. Obtaining new/better armor can often take quite a while but feels quite rewarding when you do so. There are only a few things I dislike about Risen. First, you can't customize your character at all. I know some people don't care about this but in all honesty the main character isn't that great looking and it would have been nice if I could have changed his looks. Second, the combat is very difficult. Unless you are already a hardcore action gamer when you start playing Risen you will most likely have trouble with the combat at first. You can't just mash the attack button and whack things to death like in Diablo. Every fight, even with the weakest enemies requires patience and strategy. Granted once you start getting better at the combat it becomes a little more fun, it often feels repetitive or tedious. Aside from this though, the game in itself is a very fun play and I would reccomend it to anyone who is looking for a good challenge or even simply something to take up a good dozen hours of their time.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												When I saw the standard steam question "would you recommend this game", I was a bit torn appart, because I really dont know. A yes and no would be the most precise answer.As a Gothic fan, I can see in Risen as its true follow up . It has all the playable elements that made Gothic a great game, such as the full open world , the way you develop the character and a well structured set of quests that gets you familiarized with the map, in case you arent a completionist player. The combat, is very frustrating indeed - but what people fail to realize is that it is also quite realistic in principle. Do people really expect to fight a pack of wolves with a stick without facing a serious risk of dying? The good part of Risen is also the amazing auto-save in key places. Again the comparison with Gothic is unavoidable... I am pretty sure that any former player would progress a lot without saving only to get killed by a crappy enemy, just because the fight went slightly south. With Risen and the constant auto-save, those frustrating moments when you realize that you just lost 2 hous of progress are over.That being said, now the downside of Risen. For an open world game, it doesnt seem to offer much enthusiasm to go and try to find something new. Wherever you go in the island, everything seems the copy from one or another place. There arent enough hidden places, new creatures or rewards that would make the exploring part worthwhile. It is the sort of game that if you stick to the main story, you won't feel that you have lost much, when it should be exactly the opposite. When it is a full open world, the whole point is to explore and try to get something more out of it that the main plot doesnt seem to offer.The story is bland and not at all interesting. I assume that at this point I am 3/4ths of completing it, and I am yet to find something that wouldnt be the same old, same old. I guess that the most original thing that I have seen is that if you get caught too early from certain NPCs, they will knock you on the head and force you to stick with a pre-set class type.Other minor thing is the lack of colour contrast , which makes it difficult to distinguish one place to another or even carry on playing without getting a blurry vision. Colour transitions are just too smooth.So, I would recommend the game if you played gothic and liked it... but prepare to be slightly disapointed. If not, perhaps it would best for you to start with something else first.

												Game features one of the most beautiful worlds (for its time) and one of the least well drawn women.In my opinion this is second best Piranha Bytes game after “Gothic II” (though original “Gothic” is really great, too). content:
Posted: February 18, 2014
												This game was shamefully over shadowed by Oblivion (and similar big name games). You can check out other reviews, they will agree. This game is flat out amazing. Scenery, voice acting ( Andy  Serkis(Gollum LOTR) the Inquisitor and John Rhys-Davies (Gimli LOTR), as well as other HUGE actors that made you WANT to talk to NPC's instead of because you had to because you might miss something. This in itself made the game more immersive and drew you in as each of the NPC's felt they had their own personalities - something I felt OBLIVION lacked sorely.For a game from 2009, the scenery was breathtaking. Even on standard settings, the folilage and buildings all felt natural and the colors blended in very nice.Combat, training and other "highlights" of the game were awkward at first. If your coming from a hack/slash game, be prepared to put the brakes on. Pulling that tactic in this game will get you killed on the first swing. It is completely different than most games. It really does require training (which takes lots of gold - which in itself is hard to come by). This made it feel more challenging, and required you to pay attention to your fighting, vs, just spaming hot keys. Blocking plays an important rule - fail, and you'll find yourself on the end of a booger-picking-gnome-sword.  Bosses can be tricky, but there is usually a "back-door" method to taking them out, if you are not skilled enough to fight them head on.While the game is a touch of linear - it is not forced. It does a good job keeping you on the storyline, but at the same time, you can go off and do other tasks for other NPC's or just explore and get more experienced.  Risen does a fantastic job making you feel you are on your own. and doing thing when you want to vs letting the game feel like its controlling you. This is very apparent when you come to a cliff, and you can actually fall off - so far, I have not seen any "invisible walls" that prevent you from going anywhere.speaking of going places, the mapping system seemed much more real. Must like real life. There were no cheat arrrows pointing the way. It was just that, a map of the area you were in. It would show where you were at, but didnt hold your hand. Which was bad for me, since my memory sux (happens when you get old like me).  This alone, made questing quite a challenge, as while some POI was on the map, it was more of a reference point than a "go this way and that way". So you had to really pay attention to the NPC's that were giving out the tasks. Fortuneatly there is a script in your logs so you can re-read what you were told. There was only one tiny downer. I did not care much for the models or their behavior. Their hands seemed disjointed, and most the women you talk to always had one hand on their hip in a pose fashion.  While this is no SquareEnix game, I felt some of the action of the models could have been better. But after awhile, you kinda got aclimated to it, and didnt think twice.In my opinion, at 2014, this game still rivals most RPG/OPEN WORLD games on the market today - and any RPG fan would really enjoy it. The learning curve is high - espceially the combat. But if you can get over that hump, you'll find a very rich and enjoyable game that will last over 40-60hrs (I am a leisure completionist   http://www.howlongtobeat.com/game.php?id=7843 ). I feel that the outstanding voice acting is what makes players get deeper involved with the cast, and thus explore more.So pick it up. The only advise i can give, be patient in fights, keep your guard up.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												This game had so much potential.  It's almost like a Skyrim/Morrowind light.  Far smaller, simpler quests, but a decent world.  The BIGGEST drawback is the combat system.  It is not for the casual player.  If you want to just relax and crush some mob faces, this is not for you.  This game is big on player timed dodges, parries, and blocks.  Nothing is automatic.  The enemy can also parry, dodge, and block depending on their gear loadout.  This means you have to know how each and every mob likes to attack and tailor a different strategy for each and every mob type in the game.  You also have to know what attacks mobs can use based on the gear and type.  You can't just charge in and swing, you have to block, parry, dodge, counter-parry, and charge attack.  The margin for error is very small, especially on the hardest difficulty.  On one skeleton lord, It took about 35 strikes for me to kill it, while he would kill me in 3 hits.  This was pretty early on in the game but still, VERY little margin for error.  Wolves you have to lure into a tight pass where they can't dodge attack you, which is instant and practically unblockable.  Pro tip- Every mob in this game likes to circle to their left, which is to your right.  Strafe to the right as well to cut them off (footwork and positioning actually matters in this game)and stay away from their weapon hand.  If they lateral strike (yes there are also different swings and angles of attack based on your movement) and you dodge left you will still get clipped. All that said, difficult/strategic combat and all, the BIGGEST flaw is the stupid console based forced focus system.  Holy %$#@ is that annoying for a PC user.  I get 3 boars charging me, I pull my sword and it sticky focuses the middle one, I strafe and it goes around the target and into the swings of another boar because your actions are based around your target, not just on your personal character control.  Developers just don't get how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ forced focus sticky targeting is compared to what PC users are used to (since xbox has no mouseplay).All in all I did enjoy playing this game but it can be fantastically furiously frustrating at times because of the combat.  Oh and the clipping in this game is terrible.  Save often, you WILL fall through the world a LOT.  If I had a swear jar next to my PC I could have bought a new PC.

												I don't know what it is about these Pirhana Bytes games that keeps me so entertained. The Gothic series culminated in two games reknowned for their broken-ness but I still have played them for hundreds of hours and managed to enjoy myself. Risen is basically what Gothic 3 should have been (albeit with a different setting and plot but there are many similarities). The combat system is monumentally better and you can actually cast a spell without dying. The voice acting is still pretty terrible but you can get the picture and it doesn't detract too much from the game. People have likened the games to a low quality Elder Scrolls but the only real similarities are the open world and ... swords. Obviously the Elder Scrolls is better on an order of magnitude that can't be described but if you're into open world medieval settings and a pretty unique universe I'd say give it a go. It's worth the price.

Seeing as this game is from 2009, i was surprised it looked so good.Leveling system. When you gain a level, you get 10 learning points, which you can spent on upgrading you skills.Storyline. I enjoyed the story and how things developed.Saving.You're able to save and quicksave, even during battle.Potions.There are health/mana potions next to the food and herbs you collect.Things i did not like.Weapons/gear.To do damage, you need a decent weapon and appropriate skill(s). You start doing decent damage when you upgrade your sword skill to level 7. I upgraded this very late in the game, because i was upgradig my (cross)bow skills and my secondary skills, like sneaking & pickpocketing too. My damage output was weak.My gear in the beginning was weak too, i could not handle the damage from the enemy, so i died often. There are barely any options to really upgrade your gear, so you're stuck for a long time with what you have.It seems this game favours the staff for the mages and the sword for the bandit. There were so many options to buy swords, but i barely saw any axes being sold, making it quite useless to spent talent points in axes. Even if you like swinging with axes and decide to upgrade the skill, in chapter 4, you will be collecting a special kind of armour. 1 of the items is a weapon with +6 axe skill. This is a mandatory weapon. So if you already spend more then 4 points in it, you wasted gold and learning points here.Imo, it is a shame that when there are 3 options, only 2 can reach their full potential.Combat.In the beginning you can do a chain attack consisting of 3 strikes, if your attack is disrupted, the enemy is able to attack you. If you are being hit, you stragger, making you move backwards and unable to atack. Often i was killed by the enemies chainattacks, because i could simply not move. This was really frustrating.While you're hitting enemy, they're able to parry/block all your moves. You can move around and try to hit them from their side, but they can turn instantly, making it very hard to hit them from the back or sides. Every enemy you face, had full skills unlocked. This means, they can parry/block, counterparry and break your block. Because of this and the weak gear, i died often. Often you're also facing 2-3 enemies at the same time. When you're being hit from behind, you get 1.5x / 2x the damage you would normally get, making your life even more difficult.While i was attempting to hit, my moves were blocked with ease, but at the same time, when they were hitting me, they had not problem reducing my health eventhough i was blocking. My only tactic was to block their strike, then attack, block again, then strike. Sometimes a battle could take 15 min, because of multiple enemies i had to defeat.Of course there is the option to dodge by double tapping the wasd buttons, but this has to be timed perfectly and the enemy attacks seem to be too random.Money.During your quests and sometimes when lotting enemies, you gain gold. Only problem is that everything is so expensive Weapons and armour are expensive, upgradraing all your skills gradually gets expensive and sometimes you need to buy stuff for quests. Since i chose the bandit life, i was able to buy gear over the course of the game. First piece was 500 gold, 2nd, 1000 gold, 3rd 2k gold, 4th 5k gold. So you do earn some gold along the way, but it is spent 10x as fastYou barely earn any money to upgrade your skills in the beginning.Primary stats.The primary stats are strength, dexterity and wisdom.Again, i played bandit, so strength & dexterity were the stats i had to upgrade. Strength makes you do more damage, but  the higher the stat, the better weapons you can wield. This goes for swords, staves and the crossbow. Same goes for dexterity, but this is exclusively for the bow. The higher the stat, the more damage you do and the better the weapon you can wield.  Upgrading your skills or stats will cost you learning points. 5 for stats, 10 for skills. Eacht time you upgrade either, it costs more money. I spent a lot of skill points and money on upgrading those stats. Later in the game you can find recipes to make potions that upgrade your stats, so i recommend you save all the herbs you find that has extra text other than stating "recover x-amount of health/mana".While it costs a lot of resources for me to upgrade my mainstats, the mage has it super easy. They need strength, to wield staves and wisdom, for magic. As far as i know, wisdow can only be gained by reading books on stands you find all over the would. At one time, i had more wisdom than strength, which♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥my off, because while i am spending that much on my mainstat, my wisdom gets upgraded for free and i cannot even use that stat.Things i found weird.JumpingWhile you're jumping, you take quit a leap, it looks like you're flying.Often while jumping, you get stuck and are not able to move. Or when you're leaping from object to object and you do not really make it, you are floating in the air, instead of falling to your doom. You're still able to make the jump, which has saved my life many times.When jumping direcly off from the edge, bridge or any other high place, you died. This is normal. But when you closely stick to the edge and just lightly tap either wasd button, you could savely reach the ground from a very high place. This saved my a lot of traveling time, but it is weird nonetheless.The last boss.Unfortunaltey, you're not able to see its health, so you do not know when you fight is going to be over.The fight is surprisingly easy. Fighting a lizard is at least 10x harder as a bandit.3 classes.There is the bandit, mage and a hybrid between them, a warrior that uses spells in combat. ( cannot tell much on that subject. )It seems this game favours the mage. As a bandit i had trouble killing enemies. Fights taking 5 min. Getting 2-3 shotted all the time, or getting chainraped. Seeing combat done mages really♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off. All they have to do is use "magic bullet" and their enemies drop at a distance. All they have to worry about is enough strength to wield their staves and upgrading their mana pool, which only costs 5 learning points each time. And again, free wisdom points.No special attacks.As a bandit i could just do melee attack, swinging my sword and blocking. When upgrading your skill, you could make power attacks, but that was allAs a mage you could at learn 2 elemental attacks.My conclusion.It seems i choose a really hard life as a bandit. I spent more time dying than actually enjoying playing this game. Enemies were too overpowerd, especially the lizards later on. They were able to parry my attack and counter parry with a huge damage blow, either isntanly killing me or barely killing me, forcing me to flee from battle.I kept on playing, because i liked the story and wanted to see what would happen. If i had to do everything over again, i would have chosen the easy life, playing the mage. Because there is such a huge, unfair power gap betweens those classes, i cannot really recommend the game, eventhough i did enjoy it from time to time.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
												A positive surprise. I've had this game forever and got it from some bundle. I decided to give it a try and I've never felt so bad for not trying a game earlier. The game has loads of your basic RPG elements, but there's some very unique ones too. Interaction.First thing that I noticed was how the interaction and fighting is implemented. You use middle mouse button to either draw or sheathe your weapon. While your weapon is drawn, you're in battle mode where you can't interact with anything other than hit stuff with your weapon. While your weapon is away, you can loot, talk and interact with items. It's a great way to prevent you from accidentally hitting people while still making it possible to easily start slaughtering everyone, if you so wish. Combat. It's hard. Closest comparison in my mind would be Dark Souls. The enemies dodge, parry and use multiple different combinations to attact you, they deal loads of damage and are a serious pain in the♥♥♥♥♥if there are more than 1. You'll soon learn to quick save after every succesful battle / anything actually, since even after learning to fight against a single enemy they might just destroy you anyway with a long combo and powerful attacks.Leveling up. Instead of just gaining levels and being able to choose attributes to increase on a stat screen, you gain points that can be used to have a trainer teach you skills. I don't know if I skipped some hints, but I definitely didn't know this for a while. I ended up playing 3-4 hours without improving my skills. I don't need to tell you that it was pretty hard. Trainers can teach you to increase your strenght and weapons skills, as well as learn how to prospect or gut animals.Quests.Standard RPG quests. You talk to people, run to someone else, kill stuff, help people, etc. Nothing too new, but some freedom to do things. For example you can kill a lot of creatures early and start the quest later and finish it right away with the creatures being dead.BugsThe most noticeable bugs I had was the one related to Vsync. I basically couldn't jump up on ledges as I would get stuck, and I couldn't die from falling. The next one I noticed was that you're allowed to enter chapter 3 area before actually taking the quest for it. This caused me to not be able to progress and having to lose 2 hours of gameplay. The game looks slightly old, but not bad. It's loads of fun to play and I'd recommend it to anyone.My favourite thing? There doesn't seem to be any kind of inventory limit.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												This is one of those game that deserve a neutral rating if Steam has one. Risen is an open world RPG, you are stranded on a island and has to join force with local factions and help them with their agendas to survive. I've only played a few hours at this point but the story is bland and uninteresting, VO can be all over the place. Most of the time it's not good.Graphically RIsen can be a mixed bag. Flora looks good, environment is ok for a 2009 game but NPC looks bad. Design is bland and the town is pretty ugly.As for the game play, Risen is play in third person view and structurally similar to other open world RPG, you wander around, explore and getting tons of quests. If you've played an open world RPG before like fallout, elder scroll  or the gothic series; you already know the general flow of the game.The combat in this game is quite clunky, you can equip 2 weapon, one melee/staff, one range weapon. You don't have a lot of option for melee combat, just an attack and block button, range weapon is very slow but enemies are very easy to kite.The leveling system is obtuse, you gained learning points after a level but can't spend them unless you go see a trainer and pay them gold to get stats increase. This lead to hilarious situation where you're in a school supposedly learning things but can't get any stats increase because there's no easy way to make money. This make the early game quite difficult since quest payout is 20/30 gold while you need increasingly more money to gain stats. 1 stat point cost 10-20 gold and you earned 10 stat points per level. Basically you will have to try and scavenge everything.Depends on how you play the game though. the problem above can be completely trivial. You can get 1 point in sneaking and pickpocketing and proceed to steal everything from everyone. I became filthy rich just 30 mins after getting the skills and this broke the economy. Stealing is really easy in this game and require no trick, just engage in a conversation option and steal. I stole a soldier's shield as I was talking to him once, it's pretty funny.Quest design is my biggest complain about this game, in open world rpg a good developer would give you multiple options to finish a quest. Not really the case in risen. people in this game are very easily agro if you are in a room and open a chest you're not supposed to. I accidentally agro an NPC and proceed to woop his♥♥♥♥♥and he refused to talk to me afterward thus making it impossible for me to finish a quest that involving him (you can get a spell to make them forget but in the early game I have I've only found 1 scroll so far). In another instant, I was supposed to get training from some dude, he made me fight him as a test, I won but click 1 time too much and he's dead, another impossible to finish quest. Worst of all these quest chains are necessary for you to get out of the monastery and I was stuck with no option to go out. Luckily I found a place to hop the fence and book it.Despite all the ♥♥♥♥♥ing I've done, Risen still compelled me enough to play for more than 2 hour at a time and write a review for it. This is more than I can say for the CODs and♥♥♥♥♥creed out there. As clunky as it is, wandering around and ♥♥♥♥ing with the local NPCs is fun. However, when you look at it objectively, RIsen is not a good game, there are good ideas in it but it's too clunkly and in some cases poorly implement. There are much better open world RPG out there, the Gothic series, its predecessor is one example. I can only recommend this game if you are a big fan of open world RPG and has exhausted all of your other options. Overall a 6/10 for me and recommendation with serious reservations.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2012
												Perhaps one of the more underrated RPGs I've ever run across, Risen continues Pirahna Bytes' legacy of telling a familiar story in an exceptional way. Much like its Gothic predecessors, Risen puts the player in the shoes of an unnamed hero in an open world where resources and monsters do not periodically respawn and where the smallest mistake can punish you gravely.The gameplay is simple but hard to master. It rewards those who grasp the need for timing and prediction as  Risen's enemies rarely signal their attacks and fighting large mobs of enemies is usually suicidal in part due the game's frustratingly flawed lock on system.  However, progression in combat skills offers flexibility in getting under an opponent's defenses rather than mere brute force, making combat somewhat easier, but requiring some level of brains to use it.Risen isn't a typical hack and slash RPG, it is nothing like the Elder Scrolls series either. It is fairly punishing from the early and middle game but offers a sense of accomplishment through its finite resources and respawns and unique items only available in some of the most treacherous dungeons. Graphically Risen isn't the most polished looking game in existence. Character models tend to look a little bland at times with tons of noticeable reuse popping up everywhere, but the tropical setting coupled with some of the mediterranean inspired architecture presents for a fairly interesting looking world once you get over the myriad of familiar faces. And unlike most open RPGS, Risen barely has any loading times outside of the initial start up--the world and all its dungeons are in one single zone rather than being divided into seperate ones--making for one of the most immersive RPGS I've ever played. If you're a fan of old school RPGs, try out Risen as you might just like it.

Posted: November 26, 2013
												It's quite a bit similar to the first Gothic (I've played only this one) in terms of gameplay, factions, monsters, the way you learn new skills or even how the plot develops (don't worry, it's not the same). Combat system it's pretty simple on the one hand, but will cause some frustration sooner or later. Also it wouldn't be Gothic's successor without few awkward animations.Our protagonist is chilled, cynical guy, he doesn't stand out - some may like him, others not. Same goes for the other ingame characters, they are pretty average. Not many memorable personas in my opinion, but game on it's own... hell yeah. Quests were pretty good, quite a bunch you could work out from different approaches. The thing I also liked about killing and gathering quests was that you could make progress in them even without "starting" them. For example: you've seen some kind of usual monster, but with a different name and kill it out of curiosity/for the sake of killing - you would be notified of making progress in task you didn't yet get! Need to mention it somewhere - it's pretty hard, your butt will get kicked many times, but I personally liked the challenge and that you don't rise in power too quickly.Island you're on may not be the biggest one, but certainly it's beautiful. I was pretty amazed by how the game looks even though I got my hands on it few months ago. Visuals on their own encourage to explore every nook. Background sounds doesn't stay behind and well complement overall experience.As for how long it lasts - it took me around 30 hours to complete one playthrough and I've done handful of the side quests. If you loved good-old Gothic you are most likely going to love this one as well.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												This game starts out hard. The unforgiving, really freaking hardness that makes you quit, cheat, or reload save games a LOT (death is permanent there FPS junkies!). For graphics, the human models are definitely dated but the flora, fauna and non-human entities are still quite good today (2014). The scenery might not be Witcher 2 quality, but it comes decently close. The night and day cycle with changing weather also makes running around the island an enjoyable experiance (bring a torch, it's scary out there in the dark!).That said, this game drew me right in after I got past the constant whooping that I received by boars (yeah, pigs kicked my tush and I couldn't do anything about it for a while). I believe it was the muscial score that really slapped me in the face and made me stick it out.There are two factions - the outlaws in the swamp and the mages in the town. Interestingly enough, your choice of which faction to join *can* heavily influence your weapon choices and whether or not you use offensive magic. Scrolls, which don't use up mana, can be used even by full on melee characters and are a requirement later in the game.If you are caught stealing, the people near you attack! They won't like you much afterward, but you can cast a Joke scroll on them to make them laugh which makes them tolerate you again. Now that is an interesting mechanic, as I had knocked out several NPCs after being caught stealing only to be able to do business with them later with a Joke scroll.Melee and bow/crossbow combat is simple but elegant, with the only downside being able to effectively attack AND block. Some enemies can score 3 hits in quick succesion on you if you try to attack at the wrong time. Zooming in (manual aim) with a crossbow resets your FOV distance for your character, which is a bit annoying but not game breaking.The storytelling is pretty darned good in this game - I was drawn in and actually cared not just for my character, but for several other NPCs throughout my questing.You may be on a fairly small island, but there is a LOT to do and even more nooks and crannies to explore. All the while the musical score wowed me - yes it repeats, but it really clinches the deal and makes this an amazing game. I honestly didn't mind stopping to pick the plants that are everywere all while I listened to the haunting (almost goosebump giving) music.I am very, very happy to have come across this game years after its release. To be drawn in by the beautiful tropical island landscape, to lose myself in the music and story, and to jump right out of my skin when a skeleton bursts out of a just raided tomb makes this an almost perfect game - 95/100. If you appreciate a little more structure than the Elder Scrolls series with a smaller world, you will love this game. Well, provided the boars don't make you quit ;-D

												A very good RPG. Not very long and pretty varied in its gameplay. The story isn't particulary bright, but at least it exists. What shines is the wonderful island where the game takes place. It's not huge, but it's packed with things to do and mostly interesting characters.The combat system may be frustrating at first, but becomes far more interesting as the game progresses. It's a bit repetitive, but you need to stay focused which helps break the feeling of doing always the same thing.At the beginning of the game (first chapter on four), you mostly avoid enemies, rather focusing on dialogs and quests. I absolutely love this part though many players will be longing for some action.During the second chapter, you really go around exploring every nook and cranny of the island. This may be the part I like the least because of the large number of savage animals you need to wipe out. It's a bit tedious sometimes. Then again, you're not required to completely clean the island. But I'm a bit of a completionist.Chapters 3 and 4 are shorter and will let you explore bigger caves and dungeons. I also really liked this part though it feels like a completely different game than the first chapter. Ennemies are tough but less numerous. There are lots of traps and exploration and light puzzles to keep you occupied. I was afraid it would be more Diablo-like, but no. It's still a RPG.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												This game starts out hard. The unforgiving, really freaking hardness that makes you quit, cheat, or reload save games a LOT (death is permanent there FPS junkies!). For graphics, the human models are definitely dated but the flora, fauna and non-human entities are still quite good today (2014). The scenery might not be Witcher 2 quality, but it comes decently close. The night and day cycle with changing weather also makes running around the island an enjoyable experiance (bring a torch, it's scary out there in the dark!).That said, this game drew me right in after I got past the constant whooping that I received by boars (yeah, pigs kicked my tush and I couldn't do anything about it for a while). I believe it was the muscial score that really slapped me in the face and made me stick it out.There are two factions - the outlaws in the swamp and the mages in the town. Interestingly enough, your choice of which faction to join *can* heavily influence your weapon choices and whether or not you use offensive magic. Scrolls, which don't use up mana, can be used even by full on melee characters and are a requirement later in the game.If you are caught stealing, the people near you attack! They won't like you much afterward, but you can cast a Joke scroll on them to make them laugh which makes them tolerate you again. Now that is an interesting mechanic, as I had knocked out several NPCs after being caught stealing only to be able to do business with them later with a Joke scroll.Melee and bow/crossbow combat is simple but elegant, with the only downside being able to effectively attack AND block. Some enemies can score 3 hits in quick succesion on you if you try to attack at the wrong time. Zooming in (manual aim) with a crossbow resets your FOV distance for your character, which is a bit annoying but not game breaking.The storytelling is pretty darned good in this game - I was drawn in and actually cared not just for my character, but for several other NPCs throughout my questing.You may be on a fairly small island, but there is a LOT to do and even more nooks and crannies to explore. All the while the musical score wowed me - yes it repeats, but it really clinches the deal and makes this an amazing game. I honestly didn't mind stopping to pick the plants that are everywere all while I listened to the haunting (almost goosebump giving) music.I am very, very happy to have come across this game years after its release. To be drawn in by the beautiful tropical island landscape, to lose myself in the music and story, and to jump right out of my skin when a skeleton bursts out of a just raided tomb makes this an almost perfect game - 95/100. If you appreciate a little more structure than the Elder Scrolls series with a smaller world, you will love this game. Well, provided the boars don't make you quit ;-D

content:
Posted: August 30, 2014
												Man this game was a blast. I had no idea what to expect going into it and after the initial lukewarm first impressions of the intro section I was hooked. The game strikes a very good spot in terms of difficulty where you need to put at least some thought into what stats you're upgrading and the equipment you use, but it never gets too hard or unfair. Even when you've gotten some baller new armour and weapons you never really feel safe against any enemy and fights stay fresh even if they technically are quite repetitive. The combat system itself is slightly clumsy but pretty fun overall, putting big emphasis on dodging or blocking correctly. The world is very friendly towards exploring (being able to climb is awesome) and it rarely feels empty. Just when you get tired of walking long distances the game conveniently introduces its fast travel system. The game never throws that much info at you leaving you to find out what needs to be done yourself which is great. NPCs very often have new things to say and especially in the first half of the game you have a lot of freedom in how you want to complete your objectives. Discovering the game's intricacies never felt like a chore.On the technical side I was a little annoyed by not being able to customise my mouse sensitivity or turn of acceleration. I also had physics bugs when climbing due to high fps, fixable of course but still annoying.Graphically the game is dated and I very highly recommending increasing draw distance. Sadly NPCs and enemies have a very noticable hardcoded distance at which they will pop in, but most everything else you can tweak. Google it. I also installed sweetfx with a custom profile which made a big difference in terms of a sharper and more colourful look.The story? Mostly forgettable, but does its job.Highly recommend it, both for those that like RPGs and those that generally don't.As I liked this game so much, I'm nominating it for the "I Thought This Game Was Cool Before It Won An Award" category in the Steam Awards. autumn of 2016.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												Let's start with the fact, that this game reminds me a lot of the third Gothic. Probably because of the game mechanics and engine, but the feeling was nice. I really can't find any good games similar to the Gothic series. Fable was really cool, but the TES series in general is just not my cup of coffee.I've tried Risen three times. Twice it bored me and I stopped after an hour or so, thinking I'll never get back to it. When I finally gave it a chance the third time, I finally got into it. So if you're not convinced at first, I suggest you just keep playing.The game turned out to be really great. The plot is simple but epic, and the mere fact that you have to discover it first as a castaway who knows nothing and is nothing, was something that got me sticked to the screen for hours. So what does this game have that other don't? The unique feeling of progress (just like Gothic). You get to see how powerful your character gets over time, slowly, but once you reach a certain point you know there's hardly anything that may stand in your way. A living world that will feel like home after a while of playing. Freedom to become a warrior, a hunter or a mage. Two ways to follow the plot (as a warrior/hunter or a mage), both leading to the same ending but each with a different line of quests and each with a different backstory/reasons. Before you choose your path you hear from the people what they all think of one and the other. Then you get to choose and, similar to Gothic, you can base your decisions on which you think is good or evil. Lizardmen! Temples!  Amazing music.Bad sides? No hunter game (I've spent hours hunting deer in G3) No sprint (just walking is actually pretty fast but exploring may get a bit boring if you want to see every corner of the island) I invested a lot in crossbows but even with the best crossbow in the game they were pretty useless. Great potential, but feels a bit like it could be used a bit better. It's still a very good game, well made and seems to be a good opening game for a series. I am disappointed with the second game though but I guess I should just give it another chance, like with this one.The second Risen game is generally different. I don't like it (yet?) because I prefer the first, but if you don't like the first you might like the other one. Either way both games are worth checking out, especially if you're a fan of the Gothic series.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
Product received for free
												Risen is a single-player fantasy-themed action role-playing game developed by Piranha Bytes. For those familiar, the same developers also created Gothic series. Risen shares quite some similarities with gothic series namely the simplistic yet poignant story, the dialogue which can be humorous at times as well as the prologueThe beauty of Risen which is one of its biggest strengths along with a weakness for some is the difficulty of the game. The protagonist starts extremely weak, no equipment and paper damage making the beginning quite hard. The player will learn quickly the important of quick save and quick load buttons and use them quite often. Using a shield early in the game along with blocking are crucial skills in order to surviveRisen’s story revolves around an Island facing imminent danger and the power struggle between new forces and old ones. The new ones are known as the Inquisition lead by the Inquisitor and the old ones from the island are the bandits led by the Don. The beauty of the game resides in the huge amount of choices you have in the quests. This design gives players choices which would affect them positively or negatively later and it’s an amazing way to immerse them in the world of Risen.In Risen, the player has the traditional level up from gaining experience and completing quests but the beauty comes in the ability to choose what to spend your points on. Unlike most games, you cannot beat some bosses and get rich quick which means that your choice is either to be an impoverished hero or use some of the points you gained to learn skills such as lock picking, skinning and prospecting (mining ores). The player can also use points to train their magic, strength and agility in order to do more damage and gain access to better weapons. This creates an amazing dynamic of choices where you have to decide how important money is versus surviving in-game.Risen also excels when it comes to the graphic part of the game along with the sound effects. The game features a day and night effect too which can be advanced by sleeping and plays a big part in the game. For instance, being outside the city gates at night can be detrimental due to the limited visibility and the need to use a torch in order to see where you are going.The combat in Risen is significantly hard, however it somehow becomes easier in-game after a while in some cases while in other cases it can still be painful. Many enemies have specific patterns when it comes to fighting such as jumping back, animals trying to flank you and humans using their blocking ability to negate damage.  The amazing part is that no matter how strong you get, you can still be killed. Unlike most games the enemies in Risen do not have levels. They are pre-determined from the beginning which makes it hard to start, averagely difficult after a while yet still challenging.Risen is also a long game. After 19 hours, I barely reached Act 2 in the game, and the game has 4 acts.  Keep in mind, I did a lot of side-quests but unlike many other games, Risen requires you to do them in order to get strong else you risk dying even more often. Overall Risen was an excellent experience and a game I would recommend to anyone that enjoys action adventure games. In terms of score it deserves a 9/10 For our popular daily giveaways and similar reviews head over to http://www.steamified.com/To begin your journey through our myriad of social media join our Steam Group

												I really tried to like this game. There's a bunch about it to like. The world in which you play was obviously crafted with love. The exploration aspect kept me coming back to play. The variety of enemies and the characters in town were also full of life. Even the story was pretty cool. The world is getting devastated by Titans and the island your on serves as the beginning of humanity's last stand. Cool sign me up.Then comes the combat...As usual, Pirahna Bytes always seems to never be able to try a better system. From Gothic to Risen you'd figure they'd try something new. But, no. It's just a janky mess. The enemies can spam you to death even after leveling your character to godlike levels. Your character can't do more than 1 thing at a time, and it just feels crude and non-responsive. I swear the combat system in these games always makes me wanna tear my hair out. Then the glitches happened. Suddenly getting tossed into the air for no reason (which honestly was more funny than anything)Random crashes. Character suddenly disappears.But probably the one thing that killed me, (Not sure if this was a glitch or not) was the ending. You beat the last boss and you get a 2 minute black screen with some talking. No video, no nice little wrap up. Just a "ok you did it, bye." Thanks...no really, thanks for that. I wasn't at all curious as to how my actions influenced the island or nothing. By the way, the intro music sounds suspiciously like the fallout 3 music. Just sayin'All in all, in my opinion, a game has to do a couple of things to get a recommendation. It's gotta look good, play good, and keep my interest. It looks good. It kept my interest. It definitely did not feel good. 2/3 ain't bad though right? You decide if you can deal with that. For me, the love/hate relationship I had with this game makes me say no. For my health I cannot recommend it.

Posted: September 29, 2014
												Personal rating: 8/10Replayability: MediumBudget: Worth it. Lenght: A few days to a week. I'm not sure what to think of Risen. The company behind Risen made Gothic, a series that I loved. Gothic has a tragic story, funding was cut from the expansion pack to the third installment, resulting in a buggy game that felt unfinished, and had the wrong voice-actors. The dreaded fourth installment that the orginal company wasn't even part of, killed the series, and I hear this is why they started Risen on the side. While I was initially excited about Risen, I feel like Risen is some sort of attempt from the company's side to "win back" their original ideas for gothic. It feels like they're trying to make the same game, but different. Still, Risen has a decent story, but Risen is a series, and the third installment just game out. I'll try not to judge Risen 1 on the sequels, but it's hard, because frankly Risen 2 feels like they retconned a lot of Risen 1 in an attempt to reboot their franchise as a sort of "pirate age" age game, even though it clearly felt like a high-fantasy gothic medieval game in the first installment. Separately though, the games are quite good, it's just a bit of a snag to get over how poorly they connect, despite several characters making appearances in both games. In many ways, Risen perfectly embodies the spirit of Gothic and does provide some not-seen-before elements. Where in Gothic, you felt like you were the nameless master-mind behind a gang of anti-heroes who follow you out of some misguided sense of loyalty (honor among thieves, I guess) rather than true friendship, always facing challenges in a hostile world as you go about, in Risen you feel like people actually have a more "human" relationship towards you. Sure, you're still a nameless guy but apart from a select few individuals, you're truly alone this time, but your friendships in the game are based on actual frienship, meaning the character actually has some relationships with people. Risen in no way beats or threatens the legacy of the 3 real gothic games, but if you liked gothic, you NEED to play Risen too. Fun fact: Many fans believe that unofficially, Risen is set several years in the future of the original gothic trilogy. Read more on this theory on the internet.
