content:
Posted: August 18, 2015
												Do you think Skyrim is too good for you? Do you think The Witcher has too many positive attributes for you tastes? Think Dragon Age may be too much on the "enjoyable" side of the spectrum for you liking? Do you prefer poorly designed, unenjoyable games?Oh, you know what the punchline is. But no, actually, this is not a set up to recommend Risen to masochistic people who don't like enjoyability; that would be too generous. This game is one of the most baffling, unexplainably anti-gaming experiences I've ever had. This is the kind of game you use as an indoctrination tool to convince people that gaming is unhealthy. Risen can convince you that games are evil.Now, I haven't spent 18 hours in this game for nothing. I really, really hoped this game would be interesting. Open world RPG gameplay based on exploration, with a sufficiently intriguing main plot but enough diversity to allow you to carve your own paths, is totally up my alley. The plot of this game looked sinister and oblique enough to pique my interesting, the scenery looked pleasant and the musical score sounded beautiful. The positive attributes end there.Right off the bad, you realise this game is every bit as "open world" as Elvis Presley was an octopus. You're presented with plenty of interesting opportunities, but they're all locked off behind unbeatable enemies. The game forces you into the trodden path in the most disappointing way possible: by killing you off instantaneously if you dare to go out of bounds.Before you even get to experience some of the gameplay, you're trampled by the uncaring hooves of the Plot. And therein lies about 90% of the game: walking around and talking to people. You are literally LOCKED inside a town and forced to do lots of talking and lots of walking before you can get to see anything else. You learn here that every action has a consequence: in other words, you're forced to either join one faction or the other. You're led to make some very tough moral decisions; in other words, you do horrible things to horrible people, or you do horrible things to OTHER horrible people. And that's how you're going to spend precious hours of your life and precious dollars (or whatever you local currency is) off your pocket.After that gruelling process, though, you finally get to go outside, and test the skills and the inventory you amassed with great difficulty. What awaits you outside is a battle system that... well, I don't mean to say that it is botched, but... It is botched. Frankly, the combat in this game is one of the most absurd things I've EVER seen in gaming. There's no tactics involved. There's no skills being tested. Nothing. Yes, you have your basic commands (move, attack, defend, etc.) and some extra commands you learn through training (parrying, disarming your enemies, etc.), but the combat ignores that entirely. For starters, EVERY enemy in this game attacks faster than you. And I mean EVERY enemy, including the very first creatures you see. Every time you try to attack, your enemy can attack and hit you instead. This is not something you can just upgrade, no: every single attack in this game boils down to a matter of luck. Also, after being hit, your enemies can INSTANTLY attack you back. There is zero recovery time for your enemies, and stunning them is beyond the game's vocabulary. Also, they can defend themselves indefinitely against any attack. Mostly you can also defend indefinitely, but some stronger enemies can stun you and kill you regardless of defense (this is what makes some of the enemies unbeatable). You think, maybe, that you can defend from your enemy's attack, and use their down time to strike back, but no. They have zero recovery time, remember? You think maybe you can dodge them instead, but no. That doesn't work either. Fighting in this game boils down to a single process: first, you defend. Then, you let go of your defense, and HOPE the enemy doesn't attack you. Then, you attack, and HOPE the attack lands. Then, you immediately defend. If you're feeling adventurous, you can try a second, stronger attack, but again, you have to hope. Finally, you defend again. Repeat. THIS is the combat. We're not talking about difficulty here. We're not talking about combat that is designed to be hard, after all, to insinuate this system was "designed" is an insult to the art of game design to begin with. We're talking about a combat system made by people who never played a decent game in their life. To be successful in a one-to-one battle consists of saving and loading the game over and over. It's a matter of patience, but at least it's doable, you know, it's playable. For that reason, most of the time, the game pits you against three or four enemies simultaneously.Now here is where the whole thing utterly falls apart. Fighting more than one enemy multiplies all of the problems. ALL the enemies are entirely transparent to each other's attacks; you can get hit by an enemy striking THROUGH another enemy standing between you and it. As long as you're holding the defense button, the character will "lock" onto the enemy in front of you, but an enemy standing slightly to the side can strike and hit you; but to lock onto a different enemy, you have to move your mouse SO far that you'll need three or four additional desks around you. Often, the character will be defending an enemy that is standing yards away from you, while one that's right next to you will successfully hit you, only because you were too slow dragging your mouse all the way to the Moon so you could lock onto him. Again, not only the enemy you're locked to can successfully hit you even if they attack you AFTER you started your own attacks, the other enemies around you can hit you as well, so the luck factor is multiplied. EVERY fight in this game is decided entirely by the random number generator and by saving/loading.You think that you can tilt the odds in your favour by gaining levels and improving your inventory. Theoretically yes, but then we bump into another problem: the game is EXTRAORDINARILY STINGY. Deafeating even the hardest enemies will give you negligible experience boosts. Most of the levelling up you'll get from this game will be completing quests, which as has been said, boils down mostly to walking and talking. You'll get more experience talking than fighting. The same is true for money: the enemy drops are entirely worthless, as well as most items you find. And don't think that you can haggle for prices or look for better merchants: everyone pays exactly the same prices for everything. And trust me, you'll need money. The levels you get give you learning points, which must be invested in the skills you want by training with people. To train, you need to spend money, and it ain't cheap. But don't think you can just spend your hard earned money in the skills you so desperately need, no: in this game, many of the obligatory quests can ONLY be completed by spending money. But even if you do improve your skills, this does not mitigate the luck factor from the battles; it will just make them last a little shorter.All of that just to reach some new area and advance the plot. Eventually the fights started to become entirely unavoidable, endless, repetitive, and of course, entirely luck based. I was playing just to justify the money I spent on it, but even that was becoming too gruesome. I was needlessly torturing myself for a game that wasn't worth it. Why should I play this instead of, say, The Witcher? Or Dragon Age? Or just Skyrim again? There's no point. There are many, many more things that are awfully botched in this game, but this review would go on forever. No wonder this game is so cheap and always on sale, but don't be fooled by it. Save your money and your time for a good game.18 hours...

content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												Where do I start with a game like this?I guess the first thing to do is denounce any notion that this is an open-world game. After you break out of the linear tutorial, you can't exactly go out and do your own thing. High-level monsters litter all but a select few paths, and the only way to figure out whether or not you can pass is to fight these monsters (and surely get your♥♥♥♥♥kicked).So, of the few paths you can take, you'll end up in one town or another, with different factions, altough really, they're all the same: masculine-looking people who hate you. Almost EVERY person you meet is a total ♥♥♥♥ing♥♥♥♥♥♥ I understand wanting to have a game where you're not instantly likeable, but this is way beyond that. I guess I understand it, though, since a thumbtack has more personality than whoever the hell you play as. He's boring, he's constantly finding ways to♥♥♥♥♥♥people off, and his voice acting is poorly-delivered.Shaping and growing your one-dimensional protagist is no fun either. EVERYTHING in this game can kick your♥♥♥♥♥ No matter how decent the combat is, if you end up fighting a group of more than two enemies, even if they're weaker, you're screwed. And for how good the combat is, you can't easily heal during battle, so if you don't land your blows right away, you're dead. If you wander off into the woods and into a pack of wolves, they'll chase you and kill you.So, that limits your area of fun to the towns. Not only do people hate you and constantly crap on you, but the few quests you can actually figure out how to get are your simple MMO "get me 50 of something" or "go here and kill this thing" quests. Not to mention there are no landmarks, waypoints, or any other mechanics to help you find the places these people want you to go. Why should I bother finding these quest locations if I'm just gonna get wrecked by a camp of gnomes or a wolf that happened to be guarding the tracks?So, you can't do quests. Maybe you can go out adventuring on your own somewhere? Hah! Your character is about as devoid of adventuring skills as you are. You know nothing when you begin, and it's not readily apparent *how* you learn skills. When I tell my character to use a chest, he looks at it and goes, "Wish I knew how to pick locks." When I try to use a cauldron, he goes "I don't know how to use that." When I try to use an anvil or a grindstone he goes "I'm not a smith."So, you can't do anything in this game. Quests are boring, and even when you try to take them on you're greeted with either failure and defeat or the opportunity to get chewed out by complete♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥delivering very bad dialogue. I've put about 5 hours into this game and I don't know how to improve my skills. So I'm stuck in an endless cycle of disappointment. This game isn't even fun in the "it kicks your♥♥♥♥♥quot; kind of way. It's not fun in any way. Sure, the graphics are pretty and the music is excellent, but really, that does nothing to save this game. Risen is terrible. Don't waste your money.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2016
												Foremost a caveat: This review is highly subjective and doesn't analyze flaws in the combat rules or the character levelling system as some other very detailed reviews do it. I may have given up too early and haven't seen much of the game. Maybe I will revisit it eventually, but my own experience hasn't been good. It could be due to a non-matching personal taste.Compared to my first impressions with the awesome games "Gothic II: Gold Edition" and "Gothic", during the first few hours I've tried out "Risen", I've felt turned off due to various factors.The graphics are more complex than in the Gothic games. Okay. For example, there is deep underwood you can move through in some places, but which blocks your view completely. It complicates exploration, and often you bump into impassable vegetation or rocks directly behind a section where you could move through. And no way to climb up or explore more freely.Everything is too colorful and cartoonish. Giant moths? Urgh! Worst of all, the player and NPC animations during conversation and movement are very clunky. Hard to imagine that I would want to move around (and fight!) with such clunky animations for a long time. I cannot enjoy the silly gestures during conversation. It's like watching a movie with bad actors.The open world feeling has been severely restricted already near the starting location,  forcing you to follow one narrow and almost safe path leading to NPCs that don't manage to raise your interest. Not with what they do and not with what they tell you. Shrug. The linear story forces you to talk to them about some bits only and staying vague. Just a few steps into the swamp, powerful enemies lurk. So near to those NPCs. It doesn't matter to me that some highly experienced players of Risen may be able to kill them early in half an hour or a longer battle. You are not expected to do that at that point. Just as in the Gothic games, you don't know how strong an enemy is and what it takes to defeat it. Or you try to explore more of the limited paths and stumble into a cave or another dungeon that is not for you yet. Yeah, understood, avoid those places and return to errand boy duties.So, another game where you build up meta-gaming knowledge by trial and error, save and reload, again and again. The next time you know where to go, when to do it, how long to save skills points and when to spend them on which skills. Early on I could kill a couple of early wolves, sting rats, giant moths and huge birds with the help of a shield I found, and with considerable effort trying to do damage to them while blocking their attacks, but combat already seemed very repetitive and tedious. I guess I'm supposed to ignore combat for an unknown time and gain experience points with non-combat tasks, and yet one early task involves fighting some nasty worm.To me it seems it might be possible to have some fun with Risen, if one can live with the clunky animations and combat mechanics and build up enough meta-gaming knowledge to know where to go first. If only the story managed to pull you in. It hasn't done that for me.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2013
RISENA fairly shallow and flawed third-person action RPG.Rating 4/10Risen came out in 2009 around the same time as Dragon Age and in comparison it looks and plays like a game that should have been released in 2003. For an RPG it gets a lot of the basics wrong, there is very little in the way of character creation or character choice. You play an uninteresting potato head looking protagonist with no back-story or motivations other than you've been ship wrecked on an island in an unknown world. There are three different ways of playing your character, as a mage, warrior or hunter. You are able to level up various skills such as strength or sword fighting through training that can be purchased from various NPCs around the island. It's incredibly simplistic and offers no real choice.The NPCs littered around the island in small limited number of locations are lifeless and bland. The voice actors sound as though they have no interest and everything is delivered monotone which is strange considering the vast talent they've arranged for the voice actors such as Andy Serkis and Lena Headey. It also doesn't help that the character models look awful like they've come from a game made in the early 2000s. I struggle to think of a single interesting character in the game and even the characters with some promise like Patty have woeful looking models which undermine the character. Combat is a clunky and frustrating experience, based on timing and luck. Enemies enter into attack cycles, you have to block until they've finished their cycle and it turns into a repetitive and boring game of waiting. When there are three or more enemies it becomes quite hard as every hit you take breaks your current attack and being hit from all sides gives you very little option other than running away. Whilst combat becomes easier as the game progresses it still remains an incredibly frustrating experience.The menu and item system seem to have been an after thought. There is no limit on how much you can carry, at all, meaning I was running around carrying 500 heavy weapons. With no inventory limits it means you give little thought to what you loot as you can take everything. More often than not I just spammed the loot button on enemy bodies without bothering to check what they had. Added to this the serious lack of weapons and armour, I came across 4 sets of armour during the game and you don't get the first set of armour until at least 7 or 8 hours into the game. There is also no reason for half the items you pick up, food and frying pans are all meaningless after the first few hours. All you need are potions are spells and the small number of items needed to make them.There are some positives, the environment looks pretty good with a great Island setting and the story moves along a fairly quick pace with a couple of great side quests. However it's not enough to make up for all the games flaws which outweigh what little good there is.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2013
												Risen is an RPG that continues to follows the same theme as the Gothic series. The story is generic high fantasy with forgettable characters with even more forgettable quest and storyline. Like most of Piranha Byte's work in this genre, the combat is abysmally bad. Risen would've been at the very least acceptable if it wasn't such an unnecessarily long winded and bug ridden game. Risen is chock full of bugs, many of which will break quest line. I personally couldn't finish this game without the use of console commands to fix certain quests. The game becomes an absolute cluster poop once you hit the volcano mid game as important quest npc's get stuck or the lever that was suppose to open gates stopped working. Console commands can fix some of these issues, but the customer shouldn't have to resort to cheats to proceed in a video game.I can only think of one other RPG with combat that is even worse than Risen and that is Gothic 1. Coincidentally that was also made by Piranha Bytes. The combat in Risen is reliant on a very bad target locking system; it locks on the closest target, and you cannot change targets manually. This means that if a enemies groups up on you, you are going to be swinging at the air as the bull poop lock-on system wildly changes targets automatically. You will then proceed to die as enemies stun-lock you in to oblivion.The game store page indicates that this game is 60 hours of game play, which is mostly correct if you consider that 40 of those hours are spent wandering aimlessly to find the next place to turn in your quest. The directions in the dialogue are outright terrible and the lack luster quest marker made the questing even more tedious and boring. Now compound that with the fact that Risen is comprised of mostly fetch quests and you have a recipe for one of the most boring RPG experience ever. Risen is basically Dark Souls with none of the awesome or the refinement in game-play.

Posted: June 9, 2014
												If you enjoyed the Elder Scrolls series, this is a game for you.  I'd say the combat is mediocre and only half the enemies are challenging (then again I played it on Normal difficulty because I'm soft haha).  I'd recommend Hard difficulty if this isn't your first open world RPG. The protagonist has next to no background or personality, except when he's being sarcastic.  His sarcasm is quite funny, but hopefully whenever I get around to playing Risen 2 they will consider adding more depth to the main character. A few things I would have changed is adding bosses in some of the ruins/dungeons you explore.  The only actual boss was the final one (which was slightly disappointing in terms of mechanics, but visually it was badass).  The ability to forge not just weapons, but chest and head equipment would have been nice to have.  If there was a way to go about that, I didn't discover it.  My final problem was the auto-targetting feature which would often get you killed when fighting off a mob of enemies at once.  You do get used to it, but it was frustrating every so often.Overall i thoroughly enjoyed my first playthrough. Story is the most important aspect of an RPG for me, and Risen delivered.  The first half of the game was a little slow, but it was building up the backstory of the island and it's inhabitants.  The second half of the game is when the plot thickens.  I enjoyed the lore and look forward to what the devs accomplished with Risen 2.

												A fairly decent adventure game with open world. The difficulty curve is fairly tough at the beginning as the world doesn't scale much. So you struggle at the beginning but it gets easier as your character gets stronger (be prepared to save and load a LOT).  It is fun though, and has interesting plot. 												I played the game because I was a Gothic fan, my review will be based on that assumption. You are still a nameless hero and there are some key areas that shine in this game in relation to Gothic, while others fail to compare to what I found to be the best RPG of its time.PROSThe world is vastly open and completely explorable, there are a number of things to collect for alchelmy, smithing, and food preparation; the puzzles are a good balance of challenging yet not impossible; you're character is yours: meaning just because you like bows doesn't mean you are limitied to them you can dabble where you like. Some additonal pros are the ability to use two handed weapons as one handers with enough skill and CONSMoney is easily found and little needed. Skill points quickly becaome irrelevant, you don't need to level most things and frankly theres not a lot to level up anyway. Choices for guild are very limited: Don or Inquisition with little difference between the two.  THe game is significantly shorter then Gothic. Little to no replay value.In conclusion, Risen is a decent game, and I did enjoy playing it; however it is no where near as good as the Gothic series. I would recommend that you play this first and then work your way up the Gothic series, so your games get better as you go.

Posted: December 8, 2015
												The game actually feels like a weird new-gen low-budget remake of Gothic II. It has similar premise, same plot hooks, same locations, same sound samples, same background music, same monsters, same animations, same mechanics, same atmosphere, same NPCs, same quests and dozens, dozens of references!This, though, is not entirely a bad point. If you haven't ever touched Gothic series before, the game is pure fun for hardcore wilderness exploration and NPC trolling. If you have - rejoice in nostalgia and long-asked-for innovations, like crafting, aiming, self-shielding and more. (What? Gothic 3? There is no such game. Shut up.)All in all, it has its flaws (weird dialog trees, sadly linear plot, overall shoddiness, some bugs, etc.) and gets quite dull closer to the ending, but is still worth it for the most part. But come prepared: there is an amazing guide out there that points out most of gameplay quirks that make people frustrated, sad and puzzled; you should probably read that before buying and certainly - before playing.

												reminds me a little bit of Drakkhen: Order of the Flame. the world building and quests are good, and the environment is exciting to explore, but quest objectives aren't always all that clear. i might just be dumb, but i spent a lot of time going in circles. combat isn't anything new, and it's pretty difficult -- i tried making a spellsword and it worked out pretty well.one feature i really like is the way you obtain skills. instead of automatically being alloted skill points to distribute, you have to do quests/interact with NPCs in order to train from them. if you want to learn how to lockpick, you can talk to a blacksmith and he'll eventually share his mechanical skills. if you want to be a better archer, you need to find someone who knows that kind of combat (a hunter in the wilderness?). along the same lines, you don't start out with a map -- you have to find one. and you can even hire a cartographer to draw you a more detailed one. features like this (that newer RPGs usually lack) add a nice layer of immersion, but also add a lot of difficulty and process to simple things. fun if you like challenging exploration, but i'd be prepared to be frustrated at least sometimes.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
												The best of the Risen series, sticking closely to the old-fashioned conventions of RPG -- the later games fell apart where gameplay is concerned, despite improved graphics, which just shows that graphics alone don't make a game.  This one may look a little low-res to modern players but the story pulls you in and the combat is very nearly "good", and best of all there is no mention of "voodoo pirates".  Has its faults, perhaps more than average, but compared to the later editions seems very nearly perfect.  Some minor choices are offered but these do not alter the overal game outcome in any way whatsoever.  Best played before the later versions, as often it's hard to come back to an earlier stage where the graphics aren't so good.  Dialogue is all over the place, as you'd expect when it isn't recorded sequentially, but in character sessions.  Has good replay value, which is always the mark of a better-than-average game.One gripe: there are no "achievements" to be had, despite this being stipulated in some of the hype blurb.  Not that these are any real loss -- in the other two games, these are simply things you'd achieve while playing the game anyway, so they're valueless.  Perhaps these will come later?  Oh, and it doesn't cloud save either, so if you need to switch between pcs, or a hi-spec laptop, to play, you'll have to pop the savegame folder onto a flashdrive and transfer manually.  I remember when that was considered a smart move, and not a tedious chore...!!

Posted: September 27, 2015
												Games like this makes me wish Steam had a middle option between recommend and not recommending. I liked the exploration part of the game, to a point. But there really isnt much to explore. My game time shows 42.9 hrs. But when I sat down to actually play the game and complete all the quests, it only took me 25 hrs. Which is less then half of the time advertised on the "About the game" description below, which boasts over 60 hours. I highly doubt it would take that long to walk every inch of the island.The combat is probably one of, if not the most, unwieldly, buggy, dissapointing systems I've ever encountered. It's hard to get used to. Timing seems everything, tossing the skill of the player aside. Stats seem to speed up the characters actions and damage and not chance to hit which I am thankful for. It wasnt difficult, it was just, annoying.The best part for me was the storyline, and the side stories/quests. That's not to say they were all well written, it was just the best part of the game for me. Theres a side quest ****SPOILERS**** where to have to save a man from nightmares from a certain ring he found. The back story for the rings is awefully close to Lord of the Rings. Just felt generic and out of place for a game that has alot of lore. Just a few items above that irked me one way or another. Now time for the ratings.Graphics : 6/10 - Not great, but not bad. I would go 7 but some of the textures look like they just moved Gothic 3 to an island and said this is Risen.Gameplay : 3/10 - Again, some of the worse controlls for combat ive ever seen. Plus, no way to increase your characters running speed except by scroll. And teleportation only comes about mid way through the game, so travel is slow and tedious. I also dont like using the left mouse button to do everyhting.Story : 7/10 - Not bad here. I enjoyed following the history of the island and some of it's inhabitants. The tie in to the Gothic seiries was a nice touch.Content : 5/10 - Im about even here. What there is to see is great, but the lack of content is disturbing. Also I should note, the only crafting in game thats worth having is Alchemy and Scroll Making. Nothing else is useful to warrent spending points in. Also, I had a hard time leveling. Even with completeing all the quests and the monsters I killed, I only reached level 24. Why? Cause monsters dont respawn. And after all the quests are done, what else can you do to raise your level?Replayability : 0/10 - Once youve beaten it, no reason to replay. the story does have a few alternate choices you can make, but the last few chapters are always the same. Overall Score : 3.5/10 - It's one of those games that probably deserve to be played, but players deserve to be given a better game to play. Again, it's not bad...it just isnt good. Im not sorry I bought it, but Im certianly not happy about it either. Reccomend to buy if on sale.

 RISEN Review	I have to admit that ive been wrong about Risen in the past and i can say now that Risen is quite an underrated RPG. Its one of those games that growns on you the more you play it, sure can be frustrating at start and quite demanding but you need to have alot of patience and be smart. Risen its an RPG that doesnt hold your hand meaning theres no arrows above your head pointing the goals of the quests, the quest map points you in a general direction and you have to explore for yourself, yes it will take time but its rewarding when you actually find something. As you play this for the first time my advice its to go Inquisition and arm yourself with a Shield and 1h Sword at all times, i know the appeal for a 2h Broadsword or a staff is huge but you will die alot more and learn fire magic asap. Learn the combat tricks like driving your oponent against a wall or use an nearby NPC.GraphicsNot last gen but arent near as bad that you have to gouge out your eyes out with spoons in fact at times they can be quite pleasant.Sound and MusicMusic is great and adds to your imersition into the game while the sound is an hit&miss kind of deal where some NPCs dialoges are quite well writen and performed, others drop your IQ everytime they open their mouths but overall is good.If you endured starpoint gemini 1 dialogues you can endure anything.GameplayNow heres the big elephant in the room and its the reason for most of the hate this game gets. The combat style in this game is NOT for everyone and requires a ton of practise, it's imperative that you have to learn and master your combat moves, spaming atacks will get you nothing but deaths and frustration. Block, roll will be your best friends aside from your shield and armor and get friends with your save&load buttons, you will use them alot. Use your head and tactics, fire an arrow or spell before meele atacks, use an NPC nearby for an extra sword, if the oponent kills you fast comeback later when youre stronger. Master all this and this game is quite rewarding.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2013
												Playing Risen is kind of like "Elder Scrolls light" I Really liked this title. Risen is unforgiving, there's very little hand holding so you'll actually have to play the game. To me that was the hook. I played for over 20 hours before I got any kind of armor. Money comes slow at first, speeds up as you go, but everything costs money. Combat is pretty damn good. You swing your weapon and get the feeling that it's heavy. If you block you may get knocked backwards if you parry you may get your wepon knocked aside leaving you vulnerable. The good news is with training you can  also perform these skills. Eventually you'll be pretty strong and able to handle just about anything, but enemies are dangerous always. It's entirely possible to be killed by the same enemy that killed you when you first started a new game.Save a lot, Risen isn't full of checkpoints every time you take a step. There are autosaves, but they're few and far between. Leveling up isn't particularly difficult, but you can't place skill points without going to a trainer and paying for them. I liked that too, you've even got to work a little to raise a skill. And choose wisely because even tho the crafting options can help you make up diferences, it's difficult to master skills while keeping a good balance. Crafting is cool, but pretty flawed. You can make weapons, but only swords, no axes, staves, hammers, or bows of any kind; these have to be found or purchased. You can make rings and amulets, but until you have all materials together you dont get to see what you can make. There are no crafting "plans" you just get options when you use a crating station, I.E. Forge, or goldsmith table. There are alchemy recipies and cooking recipies however.Travel is pretty basic, but be prepared to walk everywhere you want to go because there are no fast travel options. Later in the game you can get teleport stones to bring you closer to destinations, but until then you're hoofing it. I personally liked that, i like to explore in games like this. Questing can feel fairly slow, but you get experience quickly and the rewards are usually worth it. Not to mention that the game is pretty linnear so you've got to do them anyway : )As far as world environments go I liked the idea of a fantasy RPG being played on a tropical island. It was a pretty refreshing change from the typical forest and castle environment most of us are use to. Graphics are dated but in my opinion have held up really well. There's still volumetric lighting and shadows, the textures are great, and design itself looks good. If the polygon count were higher it would be on par with anything newer. Sounds are good, music is good, voice acting isn't amazing but it could be a lot worse. The dialogue seemed sort of jumbled from time to time, seemingly due to the dialogue choices the game gives you. Conversaions just seemed to occasionally be off subject. Play value? Yep! I got almost 60 hours out of my single playthrough... Awseome. This is a big, big deal to me and one fact I love a whole lot. In a time when a "slow burn" is considered something like 10 hours it's excellent to get my money's worth out of a good title.The biggest complaint I have is the very underwhelming boss fight at the end. And I mean really damn underwhelming. This however should not dissuade you from playing the game because pretty much everything else is solid and pretty fun.Buy it, play it, wonder why you waited so long.

												If you liked the Gothic series, you will like this game as well. Its literally the same concept. There are a ton of good stuff to say about this game, I liked that they werent affraid to use vulgar words, it always knocks me off a bit when people talk sophisticated in sewers and places full of rats and dirt and everything. The battle system is like the afore mentioned series, you never feel like you are a god, there are plenty of creatures that will kick your rear end for a long while until you get better skills, equipment. I quite liked the fact that every monster has a weakness, a pattern of how they fight which you can exploit if you pay attention, however in some cases it's still hard to figure out what's your opponent going to do. The only thing I didn't like was the lack of models for NPCs, it's kind of disappointing when you see the same faces in every town. Story is kind of meh, its not bad, but its nothing extraordinary either, average at best. Overall I'd highly recommend this game, great spells, great system, lots of choices to go with, classic Gothic/Piranha Bytes game. 9/10

Posted: October 18, 2015
												A challenging Skyrim lite adventure, with combat system requiring more competence than in Witcher 3 and voice acting bordering on uncanny enough to enjoy the experience rather than going through motions.Upon crashing on island you find yourself fixing everyone's problems, from orcs being too overly rowdy with bashing the skulls in on the roads, to decade long daddy issues of newly met characters. From rags to riches, you start hitting overfed mosquitos with a stick, advance yourself through ranks as a trustee of 2 different factions( one in two denominations ) to find yourself hitting more fantasy lore revered monsters with a stick that has a pointy metal edge on top. You get to traverse the maze of unmarked investigations, one thing already dead within the real of video game convenience as well speech checks, that if taken too far can land you with floor sweeping job, or without your head. Ah the possibilities.The cons :The game however, can be a bit too formulaic in gatekeeping certain content, directly tied in your equipment upgrades through main mission. The crafting is pretty basic and the advantages of advancing certain skill paths pretty unclear, especially that you will find yourself short on training points and gold most of game. Even if alot of quests leave you to your own devices in figuring out the solution, often they aren't as intuitive as they could. Resorting to a guide, if not often, isn't anything unusual when it comes to Risen. I mean, there are a lot of games to play.Overall if you know and enjoy games like Gothic 1 and 2, this game will click with you. If you like map markers and a combat where your character sommersaults from opponent to opponent with minimal effort on your side, it won't be a worthy purchase. If you like Witcher games, this might be a 50/50 roll.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												To anyone who has played the first 2 Gothic games and liked them: This is the closest we will get to a successor for that specific type of game we crave.To anyone else: This is a action-RPG with a few differences that IMO make it worth the price to play it:1. Both Enemies and resources/consumables are finite meaning that there is no ''absurd grinding just to take one big baddie'', but at the same time the difficulty of the quests and monster placements have a nice curve to them so that you will most likely clear them in roughly the same order anyway. It's just that knowing that there's a natural end in sight aka: ''there's nothing left to kill'' makes the experience feel like your presence matters more in the world.2. While the first point isn't all that unique having that in a Open-World does give it more of a niche that other bigger titles like the TES's don't have.3. Item placements ( such as in chests or just laying around ) are static so after finishing it once ( or looking it up ) you can get a rough idea of where this and that weapon/consumables are, but while other may see this as ''lacking in replay value'' I see it as ''Nice gonna try to beat that tougher opponent to get a head-start next time'' since this again plays with the good difficulty they have. Also a lot of the good weapons have a pretty high stat requirement so you can't just go straight to one of the top weapons in game and use it immediately.And now some cons:1. The story tries to follow from the ending of Gothic 3 ( the neutral ending btw ) but at the same time try to be a new ''Original IP'' since they didn't have the license anymore after the 3rd game which might make fans of the Gothic games feel a uncanny valley effect throughout this game.2. The story itself is also IMO kinda lackluster, which is a shame but then again the preceding games mentioned above while having IMO a few better characters were sorta the same in overall quality so if you're searching for deep and engaging characters/story then you might want to look elsewhere. ( Although while not deep this and it's predecessors do have probably the most down-to-earth or normalish feeling cast ever IMHO)

Posted: September 3, 2015
												My first ever A-RPG was Fable: The Lost Chapters. It is one of my favorite games to this day. This game is better than that. I'll do good/bad lists as I prefer to read them myself as well because they are easier to read:Good:+ Voiced protagonist unlike many other RPGs+ Lots of dialogue options+ Quality voice acting+ Choices matter increasing replayability+ Idyllic setting, relaxing soundtrack+ Atmospheric environments, good lighting effects unless you tinker with brightness settings+ Burried treasures+ Challenging combat, limited and expensive gear+ Tomb raiding, dungeon puzzles, traps+ Immersive character building. Your hero doesn't learn stuff out of nowhere after levelling up, i.e. distributing skill points. Instead you gain LP (learning points) which you can spend at trainers (NPCs who teach you stuff).+ Class system doesn't restrict your play style too much. You can be a dumb bandit but still can use magic via scrolls if you want for example.+ Reminds me of other A-RPGs I enjoyed such as Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning, Witcher 1, Fable: The Lost Chapters and Dark Souls.+ Fast travel system.+  I love some of the animations in the game. Particularly lizardman idles where they snap a fly in the air while standing around or look around like a paranoid or shaking their head. They are strangely cute and realistic <3 Bad:- No respec system in the game (can be done via console commands, cheating)- Sometimes you might wonder why you couldn't complete a quest. There is no handholding to the point you start wondering if the game is bugged but most of the time it is not. You probably need to talk to somebody but you haven't.- Some may find the combat too difficult at the start.- No sprinting. You can get Speed magic which is basically sprint which should have been in the game from the start instead of a spell which you can get quite later in the game.Of course recommended. 9/10. A must play.

Posted: October 21, 2015
												Perfect for those that wanted a new Gothic game but didn't care if it was set in the Gothic universe or not. There are lot of similarities, which is all well and good, especially since it is from the Piranha Bytes, the developers of the first three Gothic titles.Essentially this is an open world exploration RPG in which you don't know what you're doing unless you really focus. The map is quite large without and fast travel and you don't always know where you are. You can walk into an area where you are too low a level for, it's easy to not have the correct skills for a quest and be completely boned. In a nutshell, this is a game that is out to get you like a Dungeon Master that holds grudges.PROS:+ Good graphics for the time+ Physics are fun to play with+ Easy to get your butt kicked+ Big map+ Tons of things to do+ Many skills to learn+ Great for Gothic fans+ Fun to talk your way out of situationsCONS:- Steep learning curve for people who have never played a Gothic game before- Sometimes feels more RPG than action, which does not feel right for the series- Some humans refuse to die- Perhaps too easy to die- Too easy to wander into high level areas when under leveled- You always seem to need a higher skill level than what you've learned, no matter where you go- Combat controls too clunky- Leveling up and learning skills is a chore, an EXPENSIVE CHORE

												INTRORisen is one of those games that will♥♥♥♥♥♥you off many times, i have rage quit many times due to being killed by lizardmen and tons of other creatures. If you think you're going to be a baddass from the first 5-10 hours you are wrong, you start off as a worthless piece of s**t with no armor and no good weapons. At the begginning you are given a choice to follow the Order (The "Law" enforcers) or the Dons men (Thieves, rogues and some warriors). A mage would gladly follow the order and a thieve, archer or sword fighter would follow the dons men.MAGICIn about 10-15 hours into the game (If you followed the Order) you will obtain magical abilities. Now, don't get too excited, (TES fans, i am one myself) magic in risen is not over the top or Really Awesome! like in TES (The Elder Scrolls), you have your three crystals, Fireball, Ice, and Magic bullet/missile, these are self explanatory but magic bullet is basically a machingun spell :).You also can create scrolls with the ingredients and a quil and of course empty scroll paper and the rune. Anyone can use Scrolls but you need training to make them and use crystal magic.Combat - MeleeMelee weapon vary, you have your basics like; Sword, Two Handed, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Sword and axes, and many more like; Machete, Demon Blade, Titan Wing and many more. You can block with a shield or you two handed weapon like a staff or sowrd. Axes are slow but more powerful. You can dodge by double tapping W, A, S or D, and you dodge in that direction. People say combat is boring i think it is great. You can upgrade you Staff, axe, sword and your ranged weapons of course and gain new abilities like; Interupt an attack and more combos and more.Combat - RangedYou got your bows and crossbows (Most should be self explanatory). Bows use arrows and Crossbows use Bolts. What else to say?AlchemyI cannot stress enough about how much i LOVE alchemy in this game, its not the best but its great for what it is. You can buy recipes or find them, they tell you the ingredients you need for potions and food (Thats for the cooking segment), you also need Vials for the potions and sometimes water. You need to go into nature and collect plants and herbs to use for the potions for example a Health potion needs 3 healing herbs and some other stuff. You also need to have the alchemy skill to perform ANY of this.CookingCooking important, fried meat could be the difference between life and death. You will need a frying pan and raw meat to use a fire, you can also use a cauldron to make soups and stews, you may find apples, onions, meat, carrots and many other ingredients threw out your experience, these may be used to create meals to eat. Some food restores healt and others restores mana but the best restore both.The WorldYou will die MANY times if you are not prepared or just a plain dumbass, be prepared, always have 10+ health potions & mana potions for your safety, remember to block and use all skill applicable in combat. HAVE FUNFinal VerdictRisen is not the best RPG but it certainly is something new in an old genre. If you enjoy hard but rewarding games than risen is for you, if you liked gothic Risen is for you.

												I started PC gaming with no money in my pocket for games and old franken-pc. Luckily for my though I have an awesome brother that shared his game library with me so I would have games. Looking through his huge library I wanted to play a RPG, but lacking the graphics and processing power to play Skyrim I chose Risen over many better rated and more popular games. I went into Risen with a open mind and a mindset locked on the idea of going on an adventure as I go through a whole new world filled with foriegn beasties and skilled warriors. This game delivered many great hours of entertainment through an intresting and well designed world to explore, and intriguing plot characters. I felt immersed in this world with all it's beautiful landscape and lore, and I found myself playing it over and over wantig to get further. I haven't played Risen in a few months, but I am looking forward to picking it back up one day and continuing my escapade on this island of wonder and amazement. I highly recommend picking it up if you haven't played many RPGs and want to get into them. This game got my ball rolling to want to play more RPGs and I'm glad I was able to play it. Just as a post script I did buy the game even though I could play it for free from my brother's account because it had given me solid hours of play and was worth supporting the developers.

												Playing Risen is kind of like "Elder Scrolls light" I Really liked this title. Risen is unforgiving, there's very little hand holding so you'll actually have to play the game. To me that was the hook. I played for over 20 hours before I got any kind of armor. Money comes slow at first, speeds up as you go, but everything costs money. Combat is pretty damn good. You swing your weapon and get the feeling that it's heavy. If you block you may get knocked backwards if you parry you may get your wepon knocked aside leaving you vulnerable. The good news is with training you can  also perform these skills. Eventually you'll be pretty strong and able to handle just about anything, but enemies are dangerous always. It's entirely possible to be killed by the same enemy that killed you when you first started a new game.Save a lot, Risen isn't full of checkpoints every time you take a step. There are autosaves, but they're few and far between. Leveling up isn't particularly difficult, but you can't place skill points without going to a trainer and paying for them. I liked that too, you've even got to work a little to raise a skill. And choose wisely because even tho the crafting options can help you make up diferences, it's difficult to master skills while keeping a good balance. Crafting is cool, but pretty flawed. You can make weapons, but only swords, no axes, staves, hammers, or bows of any kind; these have to be found or purchased. You can make rings and amulets, but until you have all materials together you dont get to see what you can make. There are no crafting "plans" you just get options when you use a crating station, I.E. Forge, or goldsmith table. There are alchemy recipies and cooking recipies however.Travel is pretty basic, but be prepared to walk everywhere you want to go because there are no fast travel options. Later in the game you can get teleport stones to bring you closer to destinations, but until then you're hoofing it. I personally liked that, i like to explore in games like this. Questing can feel fairly slow, but you get experience quickly and the rewards are usually worth it. Not to mention that the game is pretty linnear so you've got to do them anyway : )As far as world environments go I liked the idea of a fantasy RPG being played on a tropical island. It was a pretty refreshing change from the typical forest and castle environment most of us are use to. Graphics are dated but in my opinion have held up really well. There's still volumetric lighting and shadows, the textures are great, and design itself looks good. If the polygon count were higher it would be on par with anything newer. Sounds are good, music is good, voice acting isn't amazing but it could be a lot worse. The dialogue seemed sort of jumbled from time to time, seemingly due to the dialogue choices the game gives you. Conversaions just seemed to occasionally be off subject. Play value? Yep! I got almost 60 hours out of my single playthrough... Awseome. This is a big, big deal to me and one fact I love a whole lot. In a time when a "slow burn" is considered something like 10 hours it's excellent to get my money's worth out of a good title.The biggest complaint I have is the very underwhelming boss fight at the end. And I mean really damn underwhelming. This however should not dissuade you from playing the game because pretty much everything else is solid and pretty fun.Buy it, play it, wonder why you waited so long.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
												What I hate most in RPGs is that story in games of this genre are usually generic. And this game is not an exception - again you are the hero and must save the world. BORING! Then, as regards RPG genre, comes the world of the game. And here this game is quite good. Decent amount of NPCs and every one is doing something. During the day he can be a trader, in the evening he goes to the tavern or play a flute sitting near campfire etc., etc. This part of games Piranha Bytes always does well. Then comes the combat. And here the most controversal point of this game is burrowed. Theoretically the combat system is good. Attack chains, parries, blocks, dodge rolls - all is here. And at first glance the combat is skill based. But only at first glance, because implementation of the combat system is very poor. Parries are useless because activation time is same as for attacks, thus to land it properly you must just randomly press right mouse button. Dodges are also not great at all, because after performing one you will stay in place without ability to move yourself or even move camera for approximately 1 second. But this is not the worst moment of dodge rolls. The worst thing about it is that camera is locked on your opponent, so you can't dodge just left or right, you will always dodge around your opponent. And if you fight against few opponents at once, you will dodge right into the monsters that stay from the left or right hand from one, that you fight at this particular moment. So combat here is really "pain in one place", but it could be really good with proper implementation. OK, let's move further. Voice acting and sound effects are decent. Visuals are not bad, but all places of the game world look almost the same. With more divercity in flora types it will be much better. So, lets conclude - this game is not the best one in the genre, but not the worst one either. And if you want some adventures, then forward - the world of Risen awaits for its savior, and don't forget about princess!

content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												Let me begin by saying that this game will not start you off with any experience or skills. You need to be aware of that before you ever start playing. You start out shipwrecked on an island wearing only the ragged clothes on your back . This game comes about as close to a real life scenario as you can get.If you got shipwrecked in real life with little to no combat experience or training it would be just like Risen. You have to find weapons, potions, food, and all the other stuff by exploring, learning to fight and getting experience killing various beasts and monsters.I love the fact that as I get more skills, training, better weapons and experience, that the game gets better. I was getting frustrated with getting killed all the time, but I slowed down and took my time to build up my skills. Pigs and wolves used to eat me for dinner all the time. Now I can pretty much just smack them down and get on with my travels.The game is really hard for the first ten hours or so, but it gets a lot better and easier if you stick with it. I have seen a lot of reviews talking about the horrible combat, but most people judged it on the early game play. You have to train and level up to get more attacks and better combat. If you stick it out and train enough, you will get some very effective and proper attack and parry sequences to use. You also have to have enough strength or agilty to make the combat more effective and deadly. Like in real life, you don't just know how to sword fight and use weapons. You have to train and practice non-stop to get the skills and experience. There is a reason people have to practice martial arts for years before the can call them selves a master or to even be above the novice levels of skill.When I first tried Risen right after it was released I hated it. I finally came back and tried it again and now I love it. It's not a perfect game, but it is a solid 8 out of 10 for me. There are some flaws, and some things annoy me, but so does real life. The length of time the game gives you: and the feeling of growing and getting better and progressing make it all the more enjoyable.One of the only things I did not like was the lack of armor and clothes. You get a pretty fair amount of weapons, but the armor is pretty limited.  I can overlook that in light of the fact that in real life you would not have an endless array of new outfits to find. You get a lot of chances to get better weapons, both from enemy drops and vendors. Weapons are pretty satisfying, they fit with the game progression and leveling up.After finally finishing my first play through, I can see why this game has such a dedicated following. It's called a "cult" game on some forums, and I would have to agree. It's got a pretty good length, but not one where you get so bored with all the meaningless fedex fetch quests where you never finish it. I loved the Gothic games back in the day, and now Risen is on my list of extremely satisfying games. I am now going to do another play doing the whole bandit quest line. The game is that good that I want to fully experience every twist and turn from all the different progression/character lines. The fact that you have multiple ways to approach all the quests, and very diverging paths and consequences make it something rare to find in today's modern RPGs.  The graphics are still pretty good, even though this game is five years old. The game world is amazing, lots of gorgeous scenic views and natural locations. Ruins and cities are very nicely done, if a bit repetitive.If you have patience and love to play a game where you learn and grow as you progress through it then I highly recommend it for true RPG fans.

Finally, I should mention that I originally bought this game from Amazon and simply could not get it to work, even with direct help from Deep Silver. content:
Posted: January 6, 2011
												I love this game, it's got so many aspects of a great rpg packed into it. This is the game Arcania should have been and, in my opinion, is the real Gothic 4.   The island's relatively small compared to some games but it has enough going on to make it feel large enough and changes with different chapters. There are plenty of things to collect like plants and meat from dead animals ( use the frying pan to cook hitpoint restoring food or get a recipe for stew and use a cooking cauldron). You can craft spells, potions and weapons, prospect to find ore if you have the talent and a pickaxe, smithing skills as well as the usual lockpicking and pickpocketing. Carry a shovel and you can dig up hidden loot if you can spot the right locations ( the slightly cracked patches of different coloured ground). Loot isn't of the uber-powered magic variety and you're first chests won't contain the 'Balzing Fire Axe of +2 Flaming Fiery Death'. There are a good variety of enemies from the wolf and boar wildlife to skeletons, gnomes, ghouls and in the later chapters lizardmen. Hidden doors are always a favourite of mine on dungeon crawls and you find these using metal rings on the walls or hidden switches on some pictures (these don't show item tags until you find the ones which work so need some exploring). It's got a sense of humour, some more mature themes and language, and all adds up to create a good rpg. Being taken apart by Stingrats and Sea Vultures at the start can make it feel more difficult than it is until you get used to the combat and it's worth choosing either the Outlaw's fighter path or the mage's path with The Order of the Flame and getting your skills up before exploring the island. These paths aren't exclusive and whichever one you take you can combine the skills to suit your style when you find the different trainers (these use your learning points which you get from leveling up etc and either give you new skills or improve strength, dexterity or talents). The parry move (tapping the blocking button) can be difficult to time correctly but you can do without it if you rely on blocking, this just makes the fights a little longer. I find patience is the key with combat and going in swinging constantly just gets you killed.   After a while, as more things open up for your character, you'll realise what a great game this is.

												A challenging Skyrim lite adventure, with combat system requiring more competence than in Witcher 3 and voice acting bordering on uncanny enough to enjoy the experience rather than going through motions.Upon crashing on island you find yourself fixing everyone's problems, from orcs being too overly rowdy with bashing the skulls in on the roads, to decade long daddy issues of newly met characters. From rags to riches, you start hitting overfed mosquitos with a stick, advance yourself through ranks as a trustee of 2 different factions( one in two denominations ) to find yourself hitting more fantasy lore revered monsters with a stick that has a pointy metal edge on top. You get to traverse the maze of unmarked investigations, one thing already dead within the real of video game convenience as well speech checks, that if taken too far can land you with floor sweeping job, or without your head. Ah the possibilities.The cons :The game however, can be a bit too formulaic in gatekeeping certain content, directly tied in your equipment upgrades through main mission. The crafting is pretty basic and the advantages of advancing certain skill paths pretty unclear, especially that you will find yourself short on training points and gold most of game. Even if alot of quests leave you to your own devices in figuring out the solution, often they aren't as intuitive as they could. Resorting to a guide, if not often, isn't anything unusual when it comes to Risen. I mean, there are a lot of games to play.Overall if you know and enjoy games like Gothic 1 and 2, this game will click with you. If you like map markers and a combat where your character sommersaults from opponent to opponent with minimal effort on your side, it won't be a worthy purchase. If you like Witcher games, this might be a 50/50 roll.

Posted: October 15, 2015
												To anyone who has played the first 2 Gothic games and liked them: This is the closest we will get to a successor for that specific type of game we crave.To anyone else: This is a action-RPG with a few differences that IMO make it worth the price to play it:1. Both Enemies and resources/consumables are finite meaning that there is no ''absurd grinding just to take one big baddie'', but at the same time the difficulty of the quests and monster placements have a nice curve to them so that you will most likely clear them in roughly the same order anyway. It's just that knowing that there's a natural end in sight aka: ''there's nothing left to kill'' makes the experience feel like your presence matters more in the world.2. While the first point isn't all that unique having that in a Open-World does give it more of a niche that other bigger titles like the TES's don't have.3. Item placements ( such as in chests or just laying around ) are static so after finishing it once ( or looking it up ) you can get a rough idea of where this and that weapon/consumables are, but while other may see this as ''lacking in replay value'' I see it as ''Nice gonna try to beat that tougher opponent to get a head-start next time'' since this again plays with the good difficulty they have. Also a lot of the good weapons have a pretty high stat requirement so you can't just go straight to one of the top weapons in game and use it immediately.And now some cons:1. The story tries to follow from the ending of Gothic 3 ( the neutral ending btw ) but at the same time try to be a new ''Original IP'' since they didn't have the license anymore after the 3rd game which might make fans of the Gothic games feel a uncanny valley effect throughout this game.2. The story itself is also IMO kinda lackluster, which is a shame but then again the preceding games mentioned above while having IMO a few better characters were sorta the same in overall quality so if you're searching for deep and engaging characters/story then you might want to look elsewhere. ( Although while not deep this and it's predecessors do have probably the most down-to-earth or normalish feeling cast ever IMHO)

												Well, where to start? I will begin by saying I enjoyed this game very much. RATE: 8.5/10 (easily)The TL;DR is that Risen is an unforgiving 3rd person RPG. (By unforgiving i mean you will die a lot. Saving is your best friend).I won't do a pro vs con in a list fasion but I will state a couple things that I did like about the game and a couple things I didn't like.What I LIKED about Risen is how your character develops. Trainers are required to upgrade skills and you can choose any path/style you desire. Having said that, your choices do get limited by which path you choose to progress the story in. Another aspect I liked is the "unforgivingness" of the game that I previously mentioned. It makes the game feel very "true" or "real", like death is around the corner at any moment. And this goes on throughout the entire game, there is no point at which you can amass gear or items to become a god in the Risen universe. Your character will always be on par with the strongest enemy along the story quests. The story was enjoyable and is a good premise for future plots. The characters you meet are enjoyable and create a desire to quest.What I DISLIKED about Risen mostly is the "unforgivingness" of the game I previously mentioned. Its like a love/hate relationship. I can admit to cursing at the monitor at certain situations. Thankfully the game has a built in auto-save at points in which they know you are probably going to die. There was only 1 bug that upset me, I was leveling my skill while wearing a ring that gave me +1 in that skill and the trainer stopped training me 1 point too early (so I only had 6/10 towards the skill instead of 7/10 because i changed the ring i was wearing). It was only a minor inconvenience.Having said all this I RECOMMEND this game as a pick up. Enjoy. :)

												If you are looking for a great RPG in a more classic way, with no "flashy kill cam moves", as seen in todays' most games, look no further. The world is breathing, colorful and with great variety. And so is the quest system. Few of them follow the standard gather and kill pattern. Most are connected with each other and do a good part in taking you along your adventure, exploring the whole island of Risen. With no doubt the best part of Risen is the epic sound track. It's on par with background tunes from the elder scrolls, perhaps even surpassing it, as it drags you in, the moment you are starting your adventure. Voice acting (german) is top notch, with great dialogues which will be good for a laugh more than once. Promised ;) Playtime is around 15h-30h (normal) depending on your playstyle. Don't get turnoff by your first footsteps in the begnning. This is yet one of these few games which don't take your hand. It's not easy, but go on. You won't regret it!

Posted: April 4, 2014
												I'm going to admit this straight off - this is one of the most memorable games I've played, but I didn't finish it. In fact, I really have no idea what the ultimate aim of the game is.See, you're shipwrecked and washed up on the shores of a brutal location. The weather's beating down on you, wreckage strewn along the beach, and everything – everything - seems hostile. Hell, you don't even have any shoes.No shoes bothered me.I mean, Really bothered me.Look, I have no idea how or why this happened, but after an hour I slowly came to realise my game had metamorphosed into the epic tale of one man's quest to find appropriate footware. But this game is biblically hard. Absolutely every bit of equipment you win is a tooth and nail struggle. Yet because of that, every item is also a personal triumph. But the game as intended - the exploration, the factions, the intrigue - they'd all become a means to an end in my desperate need to find a pair of shoes. I was a man with nothing. And all I wanted was some shoes.Any shoes.In the end I was given some. It took bloody hours and I did lots of interesting things, but all that "saving the world" stuff became a secondary consideration. And once I found some shoes, I basically stopped. But it was a very personal quest for me, definitely the most bizarre and unexplable thing I've ever done in a game, but also one of the most absurdly fulfilling too.This is a game and I have no idea what the real point is. But it's a game that let me ignore all its careful design, and instead make it about one man who becomes unhinged by personal disaster and relentlessly pursues a mad obsession to own a pair of shoes.Now, That's an Open World game.

												I enjoyed this game all the way through. From the developers of the Gothic series... which you can tell because it's pretty much like those games but modernized. The combat is improved, and the graphics are very much improved. For 2009 this game looks amazing (with the graphics turned all the way up). The game isn't perfect... there are some glitches, but they're mostly minor and don't affect gameplay much. A big chunk of this game is about exploring. Most of the game you're exploring a huge island, and later parts of the game you'll be in ruins and underground caves. Most of the enemies you kill stay dead, but at the beginning of a chapter some enemies do respawn. The combat is challenging, but satisfying. The story starts alittle dull, but by the end it's very interesting. If you're up for a challenging Action-RPG, and your computer can handle it, then I highly recommend Risen.

Posted: December 18, 2010
												While it might have slipped off the radar for most, Risen is well-worth the look. It's one of those games that is more a self-contained experience than a sprawling life-sucking all-encompassing phenomenon: you're a castaway on a tropical island; survive! If you're coming here from Oblivion or Morrowind or other "open world" RPGs, the main thing to note is that Risen is handcrafted. Every little dungeon, treasure trove, and enemy was placed in the world by a designer - and as such, it's full of little secrets. It's a treasure hunt wrapped up in a gorgeous and atmospheric island adventure - just be prepared for the letdown ending, which doesn't live up to the rest of the game.
